headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Wardell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Wardell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds and include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance and similar such expressions. 
We believe these remarks to be reasonable; however, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. 
Some of these risks and uncertainties are described in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and today's 8-K. We assume no obligation to update these statements made on today's call. For your convenience, our prepared remarks also are available on our website at roberthalf.com. From the About Us tab, go to our Investor Center, where you find the Quarterly Conference Calls link.
Now let's review our fourth quarter 2015 results. Quarterly revenues were $1.305 billion, up 7% from the fourth quarter 1 year ago, or up 9% on a same-day, constant-currency basis. 
Income per share was $0.71, up 14% from this time last year. Cash flow from operations was $111 million in the fourth quarter. Capital expenditures were $27 million.
We returned $27 million to our stockholders during the quarter through a $0.20 per share cash dividend. We also repurchased $1.4 million Robert Half's shares for $67 million. 
In October, our Board of Directors approved the repurchase from time-to-time of an additional 10 million shares of common stock. All told, we have 10.4 million shares available for repurchase under our board-approved stock repurchase plan.
Demand for our professional staffing and consulting services remained strong in the fourth quarter, fueled by a healthy U.S. job market and low unemployment in numerous professional occupations as well as a more positive economic backdrop in many of our non-U.S. markets. 
We saw year-over-year revenue growth across the board and our staffing and consulting operations, both in the United States and abroad.
This was the company's 23rd straight quarter of double-digit net income and earnings per share percentage growth on a year-over-year basis. Our unlevered return on equity was 37%.
I'll turn the call over to Keith  now for a closer look at our fourth quarter results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As Max said, global revenues were $1.305 billion in the fourth quarter. This is up 7% from the fourth quarter 1 year ago on a reported basis and up 9% on a same-day, constant currency basis.Fourth quarter staffing revenues were up 8% on a sam
componenttext:
Thank you. As Max said, global revenues were $1.305 billion in the fourth quarter. This is up 7% from the fourth quarter 1 year ago on a reported basis and up 9% on a same-day, constant currency basis.
Fourth quarter staffing revenues were up 8% on a same-day, constant-currency basis. U.S. staffing revenues were $892 million in the fourth quarter, up 8%. Non-U.S. staffing revenues were $217 million, up 4% when adjusted for billing days and currency exchange rates. We have 332 staffing locations worldwide, including 92 locations in 17 countries outside the U.S.
The fourth quarter had 62.3 billing days compared to 61.7 days in the fourth quarter a year ago. The current first quarter has 62.7 billing days compared to 62 days in the first quarter of last year.
Accompanying our earnings release is a supplemental schedule showing year-over-year revenue growth rates for our staffing lines of business on both the reported and same-day, constant-currency basis. This is further broken down by U.S. and non-U.S. operations. This is a non-GAAP financial measure that offers insight into certain revenue trends in our operations.
Currency-exchange rates had the effect of decreasing reported year-over-year staffing revenues by $30 million in the fourth quarter. Exchange rates also decreased year-over-year reported staffing growth rates by 3 points.
Global revenues for Protiviti were $195 million in the fourth quarter, with $164 million in revenues in the United States and $31 million in revenues outside the U.S. Protiviti revenues were up 15% year-over-year on a same-day, constant-currency basis. U.S. revenues were up 15%, and non-U.S. revenues were up 17% from the prior year. 
Exchange rates had the effect of decreasing year-over-year Protiviti revenues by $3 million in the fourth quarter and decreasing year-over-year reported growth rate by 2%. Protiviti and it's independently owned Member Firms served clients through a network of 75 locations in 25 countries.
Gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations in the fourth quarter was 37.3% of applicable revenues. This is a 40 basis point improvement from the same period a year ago. The improvement relates primarily to higher pay/bill spreads. The fourth quarter of 2015 also includes $1.2 million workers' compensation and other payroll-related credits.
Fourth quarter revenues for our permanent placement operations were 9.2% of consolidated staffing revenues, which is unchanged from last year's fourth quarter. Together with temporary and consulting gross margin, overall staff gross margin improved 40 basis points versus a year ago to 43.0%.
 Fourth quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $62 million or 32% of Protiviti revenues. Gross margin 1 year ago for Protiviti was $53 million or 30.7% of Protiviti revenues.
Staffing SG&A costs were 32.5% of staffing revenues in the fourth quarter versus 32.0% in last year's fourth quarter. We ended 2015 with 12,800 full-time employees in our staffing divisions, up 14% from the prior year.
SG&A costs for Protiviti were 18% of Protiviti revenues in the fourth quarter compared to 18.3% of Protiviti revenues in the year-ago period. We ended 2015 with 3,800 full-time Protiviti employees and contractors, up 15% from the prior year.
Operating income from our staffing operations was $117 million in the fourth quarter, up 5% from the prior year. Operating margin was 10.5%. Our temporary and consulting staffing divisions reported $99 million in operating income, an increase of 5% over the prior year. 
This resulted in an operating margin of 9.9%. Operating income from our permanent placement division was $18 million in the fourth quarter, up 2% from the prior year and producing an operating margin of 17.3%.
 Fourth quarter operating profit for Protiviti was $27 million, an increase of 29% from the prior year. 
This produced an operating margin of 14.0%.
At the end of the fourth quarter, accounts receivable were $705 million. Implied day sales outstanding, DSO, was 49.2 days.
Before we move to first quarter guidance, let's review the monthly revenue trends we saw in the fourth quarter and in January, all adjusted for currency.
Globally, year-over-year revenue growth rates for our temporary and consulting staffing divisions accelerated modestly in October, then decelerated the latter part of the quarter. 
We exited the quarter with December growing 6% compared to 7% for the full fourth quarter. Revenue growth for the first 3 weeks of January was also up 6% compared to the prior year. 
Global permanent placement revenue growth rates also accelerated in October, then moderated the balance of the quarter, with December growing 8% compared to 8% for the full quarter. And in for the first 4 weeks in January, permanent placement revenues increased 7% compared to the same period last year.
This information is designed to offer a glimpse into trends we saw during the fourth quarter and in January. But, as you know, we hesitate to read too much into these numbers as they represent very brief periods of time.
That said, we offer the following first quarter guidance: Revenues $1 billion 270 million to $1 billion 330 million. Income per share $0.61 to $0.67.
The midpoint of our guidance implies year-over-year revenue growth of 8% on a reported basis and adjusted for currency including Protiviti and EPS growth of 10%.
Will limit our guidance to 1 quarter. All estimates we provide on the call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release and in our SEC filings. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with the company's performance during the fourth quarter, and we're optimistic about our prospects. Annual revenues in 2015 crossed the $5 billion mark for the first time. We anticipate the high demand for skilled talent
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with the company's performance during the fourth quarter, and we're optimistic about our prospects. Annual revenues in 2015 crossed the $5 billion mark for the first time. We anticipate the high demand for skilled talent will remain a growth driver for us, and we have every confidence in the opportunities ahead for Protiviti. 
While the stock market has been volatile and economic uncertainty persists, the U.S. labor market remained strong, and international markets have also started to rebound. In the United States, nearly 300,000 jobs were created in December alone and 2.7 million jobs were added over the course of the year in 2015.
A number of professional occupations are near full employment, which is placing pressure on the supply of available talent and increasing our value to clients. This is particularly true in technology staffing, and we're responding with investments to capitalize on this potential. Locating hard-to-find talent is a specialty at Robert Half.
The secular demand for temporary staffing is also ongoing. The use of flexible workers matched an all-time high during the fourth quarter. Temporary employees now represent 2.06% of the U.S. workforce.
And a word about Protiviti. We continue to be pleased with our how Protiviti is performed. This is a very good business with an excellent management team. Protiviti has successfully diversified its service offerings, built a loyal and growing client base, and is seeing steady demand in all of its major consulting segments. Protiviti serves its clients in areas such as internal audit and financial advisory services, risk and compliance, and information technology consulting, among others. 
At this time, Keith  and I'd be happy to answer your questions. [Operator Instructions]  Thank you.

componenttext: Wanted to focus on the additions of full-time employees you had mentioned, you're staffing divisions was about 14% year-over-year, were they waited to any specific area and if you would also talk about when was most of the hiring done, was it done throughout  the year towards the beginning or the end?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, we did add about 14% to our stuff. It was very backloaded to the second half of the year. We talked about that little bit on the last call. Our thoughts are the quarter we;re now in, the first quarter, we will absorb the hiring that we did in the se
componenttext: Jeff, we did add about 14% to our stuff. It was very backloaded to the second half of the year. We talked about that little bit on the last call. Our thoughts are the quarter we;re now in, the first quarter, we will absorb the hiring that we did in the second quarter -- excuse me, in the second half of 2015 and would add significantly to headcount during this quarter. As to line of business, it was pretty broad based. It was a little a heavier to our permanent placement, a little heavier to our technology, but certainly, all of the divisions participated in the headcount increase.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just a couple of numbers related questions. I was hoping you can give us what your expected tax rate and capital spending budget will be for 2016?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just a couple of numbers related questions. I was hoping you can give us what your expected tax rate and capital spending budget will be for 2016?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The tax rate volatile as always, it was low in the fourth quarter, because we had more benefits from foreign operations than we expected, plus when Congress passed in late quarter the tax extenders, which, I guess, was the that freed up some payroll
componenttext: Sure. The tax rate volatile as always, it was low in the fourth quarter, because we had more benefits from foreign operations than we expected, plus when Congress passed in late quarter the tax extenders, which, I guess, was the that freed up some payroll tax credits that we recognized. We would not expect those to continue to that degree into the current first quarter. So the tax rate we're using for the first quarter in 2016 is around 39%, but as you know from prior quarters, that mean somewhere between 38% and 40%. CapEx, we do expect increase our capital expenditures during 2016. The range we would give would be somewhere between $90 million and $100 million. midpoint between $95 million, that's up from $75 million in 2015, 2 or 3 things going on there. We're upgrading our IT internal infrastructure to cloud-based systems, both for our front office, client and candidate relationship management systems on the staffing side. We're converting to cloud-based HR and staff payroll system as well. Further, we continue to invest in data signs, data analytics, artificial intelligence, as it relates to identifying, matching, prioritizing, both leads, clients and candidates and then further we've got more lease expirations in '16 than in '15. And there would be more improvement cost that relate to that, but as a percent of revenue, CapEx in '16 will be a little bit higher. I think the historical average is 1.5% of revenue, and I think 2016 is going to be 1.7%, 1.8% of revenue.

componenttext: Keith, could you make a comment about the Protiviti fundamentals that are employed in the fourth quarter guide, particularly on both the revenue side and the profitability side during the first quarter, it's usually a lower profitability seasonally for Protiviti?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So for the fourth quarter, Protiviti had another very good quarter, mid top line growth, much better than that bottom line growth. Going into the first quarter, year-on-year, we would again expect a mid-double-digit top line growth and bottom line g
componenttext: Sure. So for the fourth quarter, Protiviti had another very good quarter, mid top line growth, much better than that bottom line growth. Going into the first quarter, year-on-year, we would again expect a mid-double-digit top line growth and bottom line growth as least as much as that. Sequentially, because the first quarter seasonally is Protiviti slowest, sequentially, it would be down as it as always the case, but year-over-year, we expect very solid revenue growth, we expect a little bit of margin expansion, which means nice operating income growth.

componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you gave the color, obviously, month-by-month and I know you cautioned us not to over read them, but given the stock market movements, I guess, what's your read of sentiment from client, is there something to read into the difference in
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you gave the color, obviously, month-by-month and I know you cautioned us not to over read them, but given the stock market movements, I guess, what's your read of sentiment from client, is there something to read into the difference in growth rates later in the quarter and in January, even though they're not very much, but are you hearing any different or you're sensing any different, I guess, an environment there right now?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that our people would observe that in November, December, the clients got a little more cautious, whether that's due to market uncertainty or other reasons, the headlines about China, oil, et cetera, we could all debate. But our clients
componenttext: Well, I would say that our people would observe that in November, December, the clients got a little more cautious, whether that's due to market uncertainty or other reasons, the headlines about China, oil, et cetera, we could all debate. But our clients did get a little more cautious, not significantly more cautious. Further, December is always a somewhat odd month, because our internal staff has had a very good year in 2015. They probably checked out a little earlier as did our client frankly. So we felt like we had a little more December effect than we would typically have, but generally speaking the fourth quarter was in line with our expectations. we were within $5 million of the midpoint of our $1.3 billion estimate. And generally speaking, our guidance for the first quarter is significantly different, so it's mostly more of the same. The fourth quarter wasn't that different from the third quarter. The first quarter guidance isn't that different than the fourth quarter. Now the tax rate swings things around, so the tax rate Q4 was low as we talked about, the tax rate Q1 goes back up. So if you look at sequential progress, one to the other, the tax rate has a big impact.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about with perm? I mean, was that sensitivity perm, I guess, the growth rate there is just year-over-year growth it was a little slower on Q4 versus before, what would, I guess, attribute that to?
componenttext: What about with perm? I mean, was that sensitivity perm, I guess, the growth rate there is just year-over-year growth it was a little slower on Q4 versus before, what would, I guess, attribute that to?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we would say the clients becoming more cautious, certainly, impacted perm. It's odd and that on the one hand, clients are still picky. Candidates are also harder to close they're accepting counter offers, they're excepting competing offers. they're
componenttext: Well, we would say the clients becoming more cautious, certainly, impacted perm. It's odd and that on the one hand, clients are still picky. Candidates are also harder to close they're accepting counter offers, they're excepting competing offers. they're declining offers. So it's a little odd that at the same time, clients and candidates are being picky and that has the effect of increasing today's to fill or increasing the sales cycle; however, you'd like to describe it, but the point is perm was a little bit light of what we had projected for the fourth quarter. It wasn't dramatically light. We believe that current tone of business in perm is solid, and the guidance we've given for the first quarter reflects that.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in light of your comments that you just made, Max and Keith, how are you thinking about adding to headcount over the course of the coming year? I mean, you got solid business, but obviously, there's some concerns and maybe on the margin, some increas
componenttext: Just in light of your comments that you just made, Max and Keith, how are you thinking about adding to headcount over the course of the coming year? I mean, you got solid business, but obviously, there's some concerns and maybe on the margin, some increased cautiousness among both candidates as well as employers, I was just wondering how you're thinking that through?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just as we backloaded the headcount growth in 2015, we've essentially frontloaded the headcount for 2016. So clearly, in the first quarter that we're now in, we don't expect virtually any net additions to headcount. We'll see how that goes. We'll th
componenttext: Well, just as we backloaded the headcount growth in 2015, we've essentially frontloaded the headcount for 2016. So clearly, in the first quarter that we're now in, we don't expect virtually any net additions to headcount. We'll see how that goes. We'll then look toward the end of the first quarter as to what we do in the second quarter. But it's not that unlike 2015, where the headcount was back and loaded and the first half of 2015, there wasn't a lot of headcount addition either. So we should have a couple of quarters where we leverage our SG&A better than what we've done intentionally the second half of 2015 by being more aggressive with the heads. I mean, it's -- frankly, it's been a few years since we added more heads than our top line grew by. I think, in rought numbers, we added 14% to our staffing headcount  and our revenues were up 10%. So simple math says, we frontloaded, we've added to capacity at the beginning of 2016 by here for the rest of the year.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The theme is similar to the theme we just talked about. Clients got a little more cautious in the fourth quarter. We had the December wealth effect, where internal staff checked out sooner, clients checked out sooner. There's always natural project ends n
componenttext: The theme is similar to the theme we just talked about. Clients got a little more cautious in the fourth quarter. We had the December wealth effect, where internal staff checked out sooner, clients checked out sooner. There's always natural project ends near the end of the year, that's something you deal with every year. So check was a little bit lighter than we would've expected for the quarter, but not significantly so. Similarly, as we roll into 2015, Tech is solid. Our Q1 guidance reflects that. We feel good about tech, but it was a little light, but not significantly so for the fourth quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is no significant difference story there, Paul. I would say generally speaking when we look outside the U.S., the U.K. remains solid, Germany remains solid. We had a solid nice quarter in Belgium, which should continue into the first quarter. Those
componenttext: There is no significant difference story there, Paul. I would say generally speaking when we look outside the U.S., the U.K. remains solid, Germany remains solid. We had a solid nice quarter in Belgium, which should continue into the first quarter. Those were the 3 markets outside the U.S. that were the strongest. We've talked about Canada, with energy impact, we talked about Australia where the energy impact. And France, that's running a little behind for us the other Continental European countries are, but no major difference between how we reentered 2016 versus how we exited 2015 between U.S. and non-U.S.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you run us through your expectations for the first quarter in a bit more detail around temp versus perm expectations, how you're thinking about first margins in temp and SG&A trends overall?
componenttext: Could you run us through your expectations for the first quarter in a bit more detail around temp versus perm expectations, how you're thinking about first margins in temp and SG&A trends overall?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So embedded in the -- to the midpoint of our guidance and all this is adjusted for currency and days, we see temp growth continuing to decelerate slightly. We see perm growth stable-ish, the comps helped us out there a year ago, the comps get a litt
componenttext: Sure. So embedded in the -- to the midpoint of our guidance and all this is adjusted for currency and days, we see temp growth continuing to decelerate slightly. We see perm growth stable-ish, the comps helped us out there a year ago, the comps get a little easier. We see Protiviti year-over-year growth flat to down a little bit on very tough comps. Sequentially, due to normal seasonality, Protiviti will be down. Temp gross margin year-on-year, we see 10 to 30 basis points of improvement, which, is,  principally a carryover of the higher pay/bill spreads that we've experienced through '15. SG&A year-on-year was  still be up 10, 20 basis points because of the carryover impact of the headcount  additions, but sequentially, we should be down 10 to 30 basis points, as we lever that headcount as revenues grow in the first quarter. Protiviti SG&A year-on-year, flat to up slightly as they make some infrastructure investments. They're also redoing their front office over the course of 2016. Staffing operating income flat to down slightly year-over-year for the reasons I just talked about. Protiviti up 30 to 50 basis points year-on-year, strong mid-teen topline growth, bottom line growth at least to that degree. Tax rate 39%, as I talked about earlier, which is about flat year-on-year. It's up sequentially as we discussed. Shares down 1 million or so as a flow through the buybacks that we did during the fourth quarter. We again as we've done many, many, many quarters we spend our cash flow or free cash flow or some combination of dividends and share repurchases. And then, CapEx, as we mentioned earlier, our 2016 range is $90 million to $100 million as we made the infrastructure investments, so that's all for now.

componenttext: And then last question, could you update us on bill rate trends?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Bill rates for the quarter were up 5% globally adjusted for currency, that was up a touch relative to last quarter. It's essentially the first time in this cycle, we've gotten a 5 in front of a bill rate increase. Our pay rate increase is lag a litt
componenttext: Sure. Bill rates for the quarter were up 5% globally adjusted for currency, that was up a touch relative to last quarter. It's essentially the first time in this cycle, we've gotten a 5 in front of a bill rate increase. Our pay rate increase is lag a little bit the 5%. All this discussion of cycle we continue to believe as you compare it to prior cycles from a GDP standpoint, the cycle has been much more sluggish from a wage inflation standpoint, not only for the economy generally, where the employment cost index is up 2-ish percent rather than high 2s in prior cycles. But for Robert Half, we've also seen a lot more wage inflation and cycles past than we've seen in this cycle, but we are, as I just mentioned, for the first time seeing bill rate increases began to touch 5%.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Singh with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to dig into the perm side of the business a little bit. I appreciate the comments earlier, but just wondering are you seeing any difference in the tone between your U.S. clients and our international clients, just trying to get a sense more a
componenttext: I was hoping to dig into the perm side of the business a little bit. I appreciate the comments earlier, but just wondering are you seeing any difference in the tone between your U.S. clients and our international clients, just trying to get a sense more apprehension on a relative basis to the recent trends in the respective regions as you look ahead?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that we continue to be bullish in the U.K. and Germany, particularly in perm placement. We added headcount  later last year outside the U.S. in those countries than we did in the U.S. So international zone, perm growth has lagged what's happen
componenttext: I would say that we continue to be bullish in the U.K. and Germany, particularly in perm placement. We added headcount  later last year outside the U.S. in those countries than we did in the U.S. So international zone, perm growth has lagged what's happened in the U.S. and that's in part because, we haven't invested the headcount, but we did do that more recently  late in the fourth quarter, so we're hoping that, that will help see some acceleration in perm growth in the U.K. and Germany. Other than that, I would say the general discussion of clients got a little more cautious during the quarter would also apply outside the U.S., particularly the Europe as it did inside the U.S.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And obviously, you guys have been through several cycles, and I also realized you've noted that this cycle is unlike others, so hoping you can discuss a little bit more about what your outlook is for perm as we get further into the cycle, sh
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And obviously, you guys have been through several cycles, and I also realized you've noted that this cycle is unlike others, so hoping you can discuss a little bit more about what your outlook is for perm as we get further into the cycle, should we be taking the wage inflation that we're seeing, the bill rates that you're seeing increasing as a sign that the perm acceleration is still yet to come or do you think it should still be a little bit stubborn as you said earlier?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, this recovery has been very sluggish relative to the past, and you can look at peak-to-peak growth rates during the past to peak to  now growth rates perm and temp. And clearly, this recovery has been more sluggish. Outlook wise,
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, this recovery has been very sluggish relative to the past, and you can look at peak-to-peak growth rates during the past to peak to  now growth rates perm and temp. And clearly, this recovery has been more sluggish. Outlook wise, we continue to be positive perm. If you look at perm versus temp last cycle, every year, during the last recovery cycle, perm outgrew temp, that's no surprise. A perm takes a much bigger hit during the downturn than does temp. If you look at this cycle so far, while more sluggish than past cycles. Perm has also outgrown temp every year and this cycle is well. So that's not unusual the degrees or something, I guess, we could have a discussion about. Our outlook for 2016 and our guidance for the first quarter of 2016 essentially assumes, we continue to see more sluggish growth the way we have for several quarters, and quite frankly, we're pretty proud of how we've done the last several quarters. So to tell us, there's more sluggish growth ahead. We can deal with that. We've shown the world what we have done with that. Our planning is that's what continues for the near term.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate those thoughts. One quick one, if I may. On your business levels to energy and Canada and Australia, could you just talk a little bit about where your client conversations there like, are you seeing more declines with oil at these level
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate those thoughts. One quick one, if I may. On your business levels to energy and Canada and Australia, could you just talk a little bit about where your client conversations there like, are you seeing more declines with oil at these levels or are you perhaps seeing cuts beginning to stabilize, just any color as we try to understand the go forward impact energy may have?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Well, first of all, none of those operations are material to Robert Half. So we don't have a lot of super detailed discussions on the topic. Those discussions we have, certainly, aren't getting any more positive or put it that way,.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question I wanted to ask was, in the prepared remarks you said you guys planning to respond with investments to capitalize on the technology staffing opportunity, I was just wondering are those the same things that you referred around data quali
componenttext: The first question I wanted to ask was, in the prepared remarks you said you guys planning to respond with investments to capitalize on the technology staffing opportunity, I was just wondering are those the same things that you referred around data quality and artificial intelligences and so forth, are -- is there something different to it and just around that like, is that going to be all internal build or is there an opportunity to acquire technology or with respect to that?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we talk about investing in our technology division, it's a combination of adding more headcount, which is a combination of recruiters and salespeople. It's also investing in internal tools. Those internal tools, for the most part it relates to all
componenttext: So when we talk about investing in our technology division, it's a combination of adding more headcount, which is a combination of recruiters and salespeople. It's also investing in internal tools. Those internal tools, for the most part it relates to all about lines of business. Some because our technology clients and candidates are more technology savvy, we often go first to our technology division, as we roll out new initiatives. So the data analytics, the data science, the use of algorithms, all the things that I talked about would particularly relate to our technology division, clients, candidates, leads, but those relate more broadly to all of our lines of business, perm and temp.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough, and then just around the geographic comment, you've mentioned France was lagging behind, I was just curious if you could elaborate on if that was  internal factors, external factors combination of both, just any color there?
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough, and then just around the geographic comment, you've mentioned France was lagging behind, I was just curious if you could elaborate on if that was  internal factors, external factors combination of both, just any color there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, France is not a very large portion of our business. And when I say lag, I mean, it was a few percentage points behind the rest. So I certainly don't want everybody in France to be mad at me, because a single would amount negatively bec
componenttext: Well, first of all, France is not a very large portion of our business. And when I say lag, I mean, it was a few percentage points behind the rest. So I certainly don't want everybody in France to be mad at me, because a single would amount negatively because to do so, but while they're listening and being competitive, they didn't do quite as well as the U.K. and Germany.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer with SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious, if you noticed any differences in the technology segment among your traditional small or medium-sized business customers in the slightly larger ones that occasionally you touched in that line of business?
componenttext: Curious, if you noticed any differences in the technology segment among your traditional small or medium-sized business customers in the slightly larger ones that occasionally you touched in that line of business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, since most of our business in tech is smaller, middle size businesses, while they're modestly larger companies than we service with Accountemps OfficeTeam. There's still significantly smaller than the Fortune 1000. So we don't tend to do a whole lot
componenttext: Well, since most of our business in tech is smaller, middle size businesses, while they're modestly larger companies than we service with Accountemps OfficeTeam. There's still significantly smaller than the Fortune 1000. So we don't tend to do a whole lot of analysis between our typical sweet spot, middle market tech firms and those, lets call it, Fortune -- the minority of those Fortune 1000 firms that we also work with. But having said that, there's certainly nothing that screams us that would bubble worth noting.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then within the Accountemps segment, was the -- business in The Creative line of business was that a -- was there kind of a reasonable difference in growth rates or trends there?
componenttext: Okay. And then within the Accountemps segment, was the -- business in The Creative line of business was that a -- was there kind of a reasonable difference in growth rates or trends there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it seem like you're trying to get readthrough potentially to others. Our Creative business did very nicely in the fourth quarter. We don't break that out as we've talked about in the past, but we're very pleased with our Creative business. There's s
componenttext:
Well, it seem like you're trying to get readthrough potentially to others. Our Creative business did very nicely in the fourth quarter. We don't break that out as we've talked about in the past, but we're very pleased with our Creative business. There's synergies between our Creative business and our technology business among others.
They're managed by the same leadership group at Robert Half. We're pleased with how creative performed.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My last question is technology segment, do you expect that to be the fastest rate of your bill rate growth in 2016 or should it just be kind of on par with the company average?
componenttext: My last question is technology segment, do you expect that to be the fastest rate of your bill rate growth in 2016 or should it just be kind of on par with the company average?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I would say, more than likely, it will be mostly on par. On the one hand, the candidate shortages are more acute than they are in our other divisions. On the other hand, technology clients tend to be more dollar per hour sensitive on bill rates than t
componenttext: No. I would say, more than likely, it will be mostly on par. On the one hand, the candidate shortages are more acute than they are in our other divisions. On the other hand, technology clients tend to be more dollar per hour sensitive on bill rates than they are either markup percentage and gross margin percentage, which some of our divisions would be more attuned to. So I wouldn't think that technology bill rates would grow that differently than our other divisions. And for the fourth quarter, just ended, our bill rate increases in technology were not that different from the bill rate increases we saw on the other lines of business.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I just want to ask, a year ago, you discussed the potential for temp margins to potentially go 100 to 150 basis points above prior cycle going base on employment taxes, rising wages different  things. I guess, even at somewhat slower pace of reve
componenttext: I guess, I just want to ask, a year ago, you discussed the potential for temp margins to potentially go 100 to 150 basis points above prior cycle going base on employment taxes, rising wages different  things. I guess, even at somewhat slower pace of revenue today, is it still reasonable  to think if the cycle goes on for a while that, that it's something that could happen?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so first of all, let's talk about 2015, and I think, we absolutely delivered everything we talked about with respect to gross margin expansion, and in fact, if you look up and down our P&L, probably the single most impressive thing that happened in
componenttext: Well, so first of all, let's talk about 2015, and I think, we absolutely delivered everything we talked about with respect to gross margin expansion, and in fact, if you look up and down our P&L, probably the single most impressive thing that happened in 2015 is the way we expanded our gross margins led by pay/bill spreads. As we move into '16 given where our margins start from, incrementally, you shouldn't expect as much improvement in 2016 as you saw in 50, but our conversions as an example are still low relative to the past 3.2% versus a range of 3.0% to 5.0%, midpoint being 4%. We still have that upside on state unemployment rates, as the national unemployment rate goes down as the unemployment claims that get filed against Robert Half go down, our unemployment rate as we go forward should continue to trend down. There  is upside there, let's call that another -- I don't know at least 10 to 30 basis points depending on how aggressive you want to be, so that still ahead of us. Just on the pay/bill spreads, we brought those a long way already and while the environment will be conducive if there is wage inflation to us getting not only that passed through, but a little more for the house incrementally, that won't be what it was in 2015.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, can you give us a sense of how much FX weighs on the Q1 revenue guidance and earnings from a dollar perspective?
componenttext: Keith, can you give us a sense of how much FX weighs on the Q1 revenue guidance and earnings from a dollar perspective?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so from an earnings standpoint, it's probably no more than a $0.01 per share. From a revenue perspective, it's certainly not as impactful as it has been for the last few quarters. I want to say it's in the neighborhood of half of what it's been. So
componenttext: Well, so from an earnings standpoint, it's probably no more than a $0.01 per share. From a revenue perspective, it's certainly not as impactful as it has been for the last few quarters. I want to say it's in the neighborhood of half of what it's been. So if $30 million this quarter, it's $15 million, call it half of that in the current quarter you're starting to anniversary FX rates that are less different than it has been the case in the last couple of years. So if you look at our Q1 guidance, essentially, the extra billing day due to leap year offsets the impact of FX and you reported your currency adjusted growth rates are about the same. Orders of magnitude.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And given kind of where we are, it definitely sounds like there is some candidate shortages out there, is anyway to frame how  much that impacted revenue in the fourth quarter and was up primarily  in technology, or was at across all segments in t
componenttext: Got it. And given kind of where we are, it definitely sounds like there is some candidate shortages out there, is anyway to frame how  much that impacted revenue in the fourth quarter and was up primarily  in technology, or was at across all segments in terms of just tougher to fill slots and things like that?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So clearly, in technology, we're seeing technology development, the programmers, the engineers, we're seeing the most acute shortages, accounting, internal audit, financial services, regulatory compliance, there are also pockets of accounting and finance,
componenttext: So clearly, in technology, we're seeing technology development, the programmers, the engineers, we're seeing the most acute shortages, accounting, internal audit, financial services, regulatory compliance, there are also pockets of accounting and finance, where there are also candidate shortages. As I talked about earlier, we're simultaneously dealing with pickier clients and pickier candidates. Candidates are getting more counters offers, candidates are getting competing offers, candidates are turning down offers that our clients give them. There is an art to deciding whether to work with a candidate as to whether are tire kicker that's you're going take to the process and at the end of the day, they're going to take the job or whether there's sincerely interested. There is an art to deciding which orders to work, whether it's an impossible to fill order that  you spend a lot of time on that you never feel or is a fillable order. So there is an art to deciding which candidates, there is an art deciding which clients, but there is no question that there are candidate shortages, but we believe manageable candidate shortages with there is more exposure, there is more transparency to the candidate -- availability of candidates with social media, with the job boards, with the job aggregators, we feel like we're exposed to a larger portion of the labor market than has ever been the case, and that's certainly something we're trying to address with our technology initiatives, so that we continue to manage our way through the candidate shortage.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reese of Avondale capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reese of Avondale capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Various people in the recruiting business keep telling may that any day now we're going to see some alternatives to contingent search start taking share in that neighborhood, I'm just wondering if there are any new entrants adjacent to your business that
componenttext: Various people in the recruiting business keep telling may that any day now we're going to see some alternatives to contingent search start taking share in that neighborhood, I'm just wondering if there are any new entrants adjacent to your business that are -- that really matter at all yet, or if that is more just marketing noise?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I just explained, it's getting harder and harder to close deals because you've got a close the client, you've got to close the candidate. There is an art to both of those. As to new entrants, there's certainly has nothing has come around the last
componenttext: Well, as I just explained, it's getting harder and harder to close deals because you've got a close the client, you've got to close the candidate. There is an art to both of those. As to new entrants, there's certainly has nothing has come around the last -- in the last couple of years. We've talked about LinkedIn at length in calls past, and LinkedIn is still there, it's A source, it's not B source of perm candidates for us. It's not particularly impactful to sourcing candidates for our temporary businesses. So on balance, are there any new entrants that are moving the needle, I'd say no.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are there any sources of candidates coming out of weaker industries that might help a little bit as we go through '16?
componenttext: Are there any sources of candidates coming out of weaker industries that might help a little bit as we go through '16?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our candidates tend to be geographically focused. So if we're talking Houston, so clearly, we have Houston oil and gas candidates that are freed up by those economic conditions, but for the most part, they're available to the Houston market and not
componenttext: Well, our candidates tend to be geographically focused. So if we're talking Houston, so clearly, we have Houston oil and gas candidates that are freed up by those economic conditions, but for the most part, they're available to the Houston market and not available to the markets all over the country. So there is some availability created by pockets of weakness, but it's not like we can transport everybody around the country to fill a 3-month engagement in Boston because we have some available in Houston. For the most part, it's a local business particularly as a local business that's confined in the local market.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's been a few years since we've seen U.S. Protiviti be sequentially down in revenue in the fourth quarter, is there any message there or any carryover or is it more of a timing issue?
componenttext: It's been a few years since we've seen U.S. Protiviti be sequentially down in revenue in the fourth quarter, is there any message there or any carryover or is it more of a timing issue?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's remember now that year-on-year Protiviti grew 15% on monster comps. So Protiviti had a wonderful fourth quarter. It is true that during the fourth quarter and the financial services regulatory compliance area, they had a couple of projects tha
componenttext: Well, let's remember now that year-on-year Protiviti grew 15% on monster comps. So Protiviti had a wonderful fourth quarter. It is true that during the fourth quarter and the financial services regulatory compliance area, they had a couple of projects that ended earlier than expected. They had 1 larger project where the client ran out a budget and delayed the project for a few weeks until the New Year when they got a new budget. So there is always going to be project variation with Protiviti. And by the way, Management Resources, which nobody has asked about, it actually did better than the expectation in the fourth quarter sequentially and year-on-year, and it's just the opposite story where again in financial services, they had some good projects come online better than expectation. So project -- project timing hurt Protiviti a little bit, project timing helped Management Resources. So it's just kind of the ebb and flow of projects that impacts those results. So there's nothing particularly shattering about Protiviti's fourth quarter sequential performance. And here again, Protiviti had a great quarter, Protiviti had a great year, they've had the toughest comps, they've grown the fastest top line and bottom line, profitability 14% for the quarter is wonderful. We're at that mid double-digit profitability level talked about, we couldn't be happier with Protiviti, but there is project variability in the revenues.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I learned from every quarter, I'm not used to seeing you beat my expectations in temp staffing, and miss on the perm side, usually, when one is stronger, the other one doesn't  fall short, but this is an interesting environment.
componenttext: Yes, I learned from every quarter, I'm not used to seeing you beat my expectations in temp staffing, and miss on the perm side, usually, when one is stronger, the other one doesn't  fall short, but this is an interesting environment.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, I'd like to further explore the growth outlook for Protiviti, what trends are you seeing in pricing, in competitive dynamics, customer demand and customer penetration that could have contributed to the deceleration in growth and that might impact l
componenttext: Keith, I'd like to further explore the growth outlook for Protiviti, what trends are you seeing in pricing, in competitive dynamics, customer demand and customer penetration that could have contributed to the deceleration in growth and that might impact longer-term growth?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so the deceleration in growth we're talking about rather than growing 20%, on 20% on 20%, we're staggered on 15% on tough comps. So it's certainly isn't viewed as a major issue that Protiviti slow down from 20% to 15%. The underlying trends and inte
componenttext: Well, so the deceleration in growth we're talking about rather than growing 20%, on 20% on 20%, we're staggered on 15% on tough comps. So it's certainly isn't viewed as a major issue that Protiviti slow down from 20% to 15%. The underlying trends and internal audit, financial services, regulatory compliance, technology, security, privacy, infrastructure, we did a small acquisition during the quarter that relates to IT, business intelligence, data analytics, we're very proud to have of our team. We feel good about Protiviti. We feel good about its prospects. We posted very good numbers for 2 or 3 years running. We expect that to follow into 2016 competitively. We're very well-positioned against the big 4. We believe we've got level resources that are much more responsive and much more agile for clients given our relative sizes. So.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And I guess, as a followup -- Max, follow-up on the question around the rebound in international markets, can you provide some data point that show which verticals or end markets by seeing the most positive  inflection?

componenttext: Well, we talked about the U.K. and Germany of course, and they've been strong more or less across the board, I would argue.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's just not necessarily any verticals. Just as we're on the United States, we're very diversified. We don't have a huge client concentration by industry, et cetera, and therefore, while our non-U.S. clients are modestly larger than our U.S. clients
componenttext: Yes, it's just not necessarily any verticals. Just as we're on the United States, we're very diversified. We don't have a huge client concentration by industry, et cetera, and therefore, while our non-U.S. clients are modestly larger than our U.S. clients, we still don't have any big concentration.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Mark Marcon with Baird.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Mark Marcon with Baird.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering are you seeing anything that's different in California or elsewhere on the regulatory front that's impacting the business in any way shape or form?
componenttext: I was just wondering are you seeing anything that's different in California or elsewhere on the regulatory front that's impacting the business in any way shape or form?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the only regulatory thing I can think of, there are sick pay regulators that initially were limited to Northern California, San Francisco, more specifically, that have now been extended statewide. There are a few others city/states around the countr
componenttext: Well, the only regulatory thing I can think of, there are sick pay regulators that initially were limited to Northern California, San Francisco, more specifically, that have now been extended statewide. There are a few others city/states around the country that have also mandated sick pay benefits for temporary employees. Those put a little bit of pressure on gross margin. We're trying to pass those through. But I can't think of regulatory requirement -- a new regulatory requirement that -- that's moving the needle in any way.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not exactly response of your question, but let me just add that I was at a business meeting with a bunch of CEOs recently, and it was noted that there are over 75,000 pages in Federal Register this year alone, I would say that the regulatory state is
componenttext: It's not exactly response of your question, but let me just add that I was at a business meeting with a bunch of CEOs recently, and it was noted that there are over 75,000 pages in Federal Register this year alone, I would say that the regulatory state is a great ally of Robert Half we live in an environment where there are more and more rules and regulations we're in the business and helping deal with those. So on a positive note, regulations can be our friend as well as our enemy.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds and include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance and similar such expressions.
We believe these remarks to be reasonable; however, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. 
Some of these risks and uncertainties are described in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and today's 8-K. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on today's call. For your convenience, our prepared remarks also are available on our website at roberthalf.com. From the About Us tab, go to our Investor Center, where you will find the Quarterly Conference Calls link.
Now let's review our fourth quarter 2015 results. Quarterly revenues were $1.305 billion, up 7% from the fourth quarter a year ago, or up 9% on a same-day, constant-currency basis.
Income per share was $0.71, up 14% from this time last year. Cash flow from operations was $111 million in the fourth quarter. Capital expenditures were $27 million.
We returned $27 million to our stockholders during the quarter through a $0.20 per share cash dividend. We also repurchased $1.4 million Robert Half shares for $67 million.
In October, our Board of Directors approved the repurchase from time-to-time of an additional 10 million shares of common stock. All told, we have 10.4 million shares available for repurchase under our board-approved stock repurchase plan.
Demand for our professional staffing and consulting services remained strong in the fourth quarter, fueled by a healthy U.S. job market and low unemployment in numerous professional occupations as well as a more positive economic backdrop in many of our non-U.S. markets.
We saw year-over-year revenue growth across the board and our staffing and consulting operations, both in the United States and abroad.
This was the company's 23rd straight quarter of double-digit net income and earnings per share percentage growth on a year-over-year basis. Our unlevered return on equity was 37%.
I'll turn the call over to Keith now for a closer look at our fourth quarter results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As Max said, global revenues were $1.305 billion in the fourth quarter. This is up 7% from the fourth quarter a year ago on a reported basis and up 9% on a same-day, constant currency basis.Fourth quarter staffing revenues were up 8% on a sam
componenttext:
Thank you. As Max said, global revenues were $1.305 billion in the fourth quarter. This is up 7% from the fourth quarter a year ago on a reported basis and up 9% on a same-day, constant currency basis.
Fourth quarter staffing revenues were up 8% on a same-day, constant-currency basis. U.S. staffing revenues were $892 million in the fourth quarter, up 8%. Non-U.S. staffing revenues were $217 million, up 4% when adjusted for billing days and currency exchange rates. We have 332 staffing locations worldwide, including 92 locations in 17 countries outside the U.S.
The fourth quarter had 62.3 billing days compared to 61.7 days in the fourth quarter a year ago. The current first quarter has 62.7 billing days compared to 62 days in the first quarter of last year.
Accompanying our earnings release is a supplemental schedule showing year-over-year revenue growth rates for our staffing lines of business on both the reported and same-day, constant-currency basis. This is further broken down by U.S. and non-U.S. operations. This is a non-GAAP financial measure that offers insight into certain revenue trends in our operations.
Currency-exchange rates had the effect of decreasing reported year-over-year staffing revenues by $30 million in the fourth quarter. Exchange rates also decreased year-over-year reported staffing growth rates by 3 points.
Global revenues for Protiviti were $195 million in the fourth quarter, with $164 million in revenues in the United States and $31 million in revenues outside the U.S. Protiviti revenues were up 15% year-over-year on a same-day, constant-currency basis. U.S. revenues were up 15%, and non-U.S. revenues were up 17% from the prior year.
Exchange rates had the effect of decreasing year-over-year Protiviti revenues by $3 million in the fourth quarter and decreasing year-over-year reported growth rate by 2%. Protiviti and it's independently owned Member Firms served clients through a network of 75 locations in 25 countries.
Gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations in the fourth quarter was 37.3% of applicable revenues. This is a 40-basis-point improvement from the same period a year ago. The improvement relates primarily to higher pay/bill spreads. The fourth quarter of 2015 also includes $1.2 million workers' compensation and other payroll-related credits.
Fourth quarter revenues for our permanent placement operations were 9.2% of consolidated staffing revenues, which is unchanged from last year's fourth quarter. Together with temporary and consulting gross margin, overall staffing gross margin improved 40 basis points versus a year ago to 43.0%.
Fourth quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $62 million or 32% of Protiviti revenues. Gross margin 1 year ago for Protiviti was $53 million or 30.7% of Protiviti revenues.
Staffing SG&A costs were 32.5% of staffing revenues in the fourth quarter versus 32.0% in last year's fourth quarter. We ended 2015 with 12,800 full-time employees in our staffing divisions, up 14% from the prior year.
SG&A costs for Protiviti were 18% of Protiviti revenues in the fourth quarter compared to 18.3% of Protiviti revenues in the year-ago period. We ended 2015 with 3,800 full-time Protiviti employees and contractors, up 15% from the prior year.
Operating income from our staffing operations was $117 million in the fourth quarter, up 5% from the prior year. Operating margin was 10.5%. Our temporary and consulting staffing divisions reported $99 million in operating income, an increase of 5% over the prior year. This resulted in an operating margin of 9.9%. Operating income for our permanent placement division was $18 million in the fourth quarter, up 2% from the prior year and producing an operating margin of 17.3%.
Fourth quarter operating profit for Protiviti was $27 million, an increase of 29% from the prior year. This produced an operating margin of 14.0%.
At the end of the fourth quarter, accounts receivable were $705 million. Implied day sales outstanding, DSO, was 49.2 days.
Before we move to first quarter guidance, let's review the monthly revenue trends we saw in the fourth quarter and in January, all adjusted for currency.
Globally, year-over-year revenue growth rates for our temporary and consulting staffing divisions accelerated modestly in October then decelerated the latter part of the quarter. 
We exited the quarter with December growing 6% compared to 7% for the full fourth quarter. Revenue growth for the first 3 weeks of January was also up 6% compared to the prior year.
Global permanent placement revenue growth rates also accelerated in October, then moderated the balance of the quarter, with December growing 8% compared to 8% for the full quarter. And in for the first 4 weeks in January, permanent placement revenues increased 7% compared to the same period last year.
This information is designed to offer a glimpse into trends we saw during the fourth quarter and in January. But as you know, we hesitate to read too much into these numbers as they represent very brief periods of time.
That said, we offer the following first quarter guidance: Revenues $1,270,000,000 to $1,330,000,000. Income per share, $0.61 to $0.67.
The midpoint of our guidance implies year-over-year revenue growth of 8% on a reported basis and adjusted for currency including Protiviti and EPS growth of 10%.
We limit our guidance to 1 quarter. All estimates we provide on the call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release and in our SEC filings.
Now I'll turn the call back over to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with the company's performance during the fourth quarter, and we are optimistic about our prospects. Annual revenues in 2015 crossed the $5 billion mark for the first time. We anticipate the high demand for skilled talent
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with the company's performance during the fourth quarter, and we are optimistic about our prospects. Annual revenues in 2015 crossed the $5 billion mark for the first time. We anticipate the high demand for skilled talent will remain a growth driver for us, and we have every confidence in the opportunities ahead for Protiviti.
While the stock market has been volatile and economic uncertainty persists, the U.S. labor market remained strong, and international markets have also started to rebound. In the United States, nearly 300,000 jobs were created in December alone and 2.7 million jobs were added over the course of the year in 2015.
A number of professional occupations are near full employment, which is placing pressure on the supply of available talent and increasing our value to clients. This is particularly true in technology staffing, and we are responding with investments to capitalize on this potential. Locating hard-to-find talent is a specialty at Robert Half.
The secular demand for temporary staffing also is ongoing. The use of flexible workers matched an all-time high during the fourth quarter. Temporary employees now represent 2.06% of the U.S. workforce.
And a word about Protiviti. We continue to be pleased with how Protiviti is performed. This is a very good business with an excellent management team. Protiviti has successfully diversified its service offerings, built a loyal and growing client base, and is seeing steady demand in all of its major consulting segments. Protiviti serves its clients in areas such as internal audit and financial advisory services, risk and compliance, and information technology consulting, among others. 
At this time, Keith and I would be happy to answer questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to focus on the additions of full-time employees. You had mentioned your staffing division's, I think, you said it was up about 14% year-over-year. Were they weighted to any specific area and if you'd also talk about when was most of the hiring don
componenttext: Wanted to focus on the additions of full-time employees. You had mentioned your staffing division's, I think, you said it was up about 14% year-over-year. Were they weighted to any specific area and if you'd also talk about when was most of the hiring done, was it done throughout the year, towards the beginning, or the end?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, we did add about 14% to our staff. It was very backloaded to the second half of the year. We talked about that little bit on the last call. Our thoughts are: the quarter we're now in, the first quarter, we will absorb the hiring that we did in the s
componenttext: Jeff, we did add about 14% to our staff. It was very backloaded to the second half of the year. We talked about that little bit on the last call. Our thoughts are: the quarter we're now in, the first quarter, we will absorb the hiring that we did in the second quarter -- excuse me, in the second half of 2015 and wouldn't add significantly to headcount during this quarter. As to line of business, it was pretty broad based. It was a little a heavier toward permanent placement, a little heavier toward technology, but certainly, all of the divisions participated in the headcount increase.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a couple of numbers related questions. I was hoping you can give us what your expected tax rate and capital spending budget will be for 2016?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a couple of numbers related questions. I was hoping you can give us what your expected tax rate and capital spending budget will be for 2016?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The tax rate, volatile as always, it was low in the fourth quarter, because we had more benefits from foreign operations than we expected, plus when Congress passed in late quarter the tax extenders, which, I guess, was the PATH Act that freed up so
componenttext: Sure. The tax rate, volatile as always, it was low in the fourth quarter, because we had more benefits from foreign operations than we expected, plus when Congress passed in late quarter the tax extenders, which, I guess, was the PATH Act that freed up some payroll tax credits that we recognized. We would not expect those to continue to that degree into the current first quarter. So the tax rate we're using for the first quarter and 2016 is around 39%, but as you know from prior quarters, that means somewhere between 38% and 40%. CapEx, we do expect increase to our capital expenditures during 2016. The range we would give would be somewhere between $90 million and $100 million. Midpoint would be $95 million, that's up from $75 million in 2015. Two or three things going on there. We're upgrading our IT internal infrastructure to cloud-based systems, both for our front office, client and candidate relationship management systems on the staffing side. We're converting to cloud-based HR and staff payroll system as well. Further, we continue to invest in data science, data analytics, artificial intelligence, as it relates to identifying, matching, prioritizing, both leads, clients and candidates and then further, we've got more lease expirations in '16 than in '15. And there would be more tenant improvement cost that relate to that. But as a percent of revenue, CapEx in '16 will be a little bit higher. I think the historical average is 1.5% of revenue, and I think 2016, it's going to be 1.7%, 1.8% of revenue.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Keith, could you make a comment about the Protiviti fundamentals that are implied in the fourth quarter guide, particularly on both the revenue side and the profitability side, noting the first quarter? It's usually a lower profitability seasonally for Protiviti.

componenttext: Sure. So for the fourth quarter, Protiviti had another very good quarter, mid top line growth, much better than that bottom line growth. Going into the first quarter, year-on-year, we would, again, expect a mid-double digit top line growth and bottom line growth, at least as much as that. Sequentially -- because the first quarter seasonally is Protiviti's slowest, sequentially, it would be down as it is -- as always the case, but year-over-year, we expect very solid revenue growth, we expect a little bit of margin expansion, which means nice operating income growth.
