headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: BSA, BLS? I guess, I would observe that over long, long periods of time we haven't tracked all that closely to either BLS or ASA [ph]. It was kind of interesting this morning, PMI services came out. And if you look at the employment piece of PMI services,
componenttext: BSA, BLS? I guess, I would observe that over long, long periods of time we haven't tracked all that closely to either BLS or ASA [ph]. It was kind of interesting this morning, PMI services came out. And if you look at the employment piece of PMI services, and I don't call it out because it's the thing but it just happened to come out this morning. But if you look at the employment portion of PMI services, it continues to trend down as late as until today. So I -- we've never track that closely to the external index as you talked about. Traditionally, they've been very commercial staffing, light industrial production staffing centric. So sometimes, we're better. Sometimes, we're worse, but rarely do we take that much stock in those external indexes.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I wonder if I'd get a little more color on Protiviti. It sounds you've referenced earlier that the weaker demand from financial compliance, et cetera, I guess, it sounds like that continues. How it -- any end of the -- light at the end of the tunn
componenttext: Just -- I wonder if I'd get a little more color on Protiviti. It sounds you've referenced earlier that the weaker demand from financial compliance, et cetera, I guess, it sounds like that continues. How it -- any end of the -- light at the end of the tunnel there? And is the pricing pressure you've referenced in the past still a factor with that end market?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Protiviti grew 8% on very tough comps. They grew 23% a year ago, very tough comps. The U.S. was solid. Non-U.S. was very strong. Australia, Japan, solid in EU. So from a revenue standpoint, Protiviti's third quarter was pretty much spot on what we e
componenttext: Well, Protiviti grew 8% on very tough comps. They grew 23% a year ago, very tough comps. The U.S. was solid. Non-U.S. was very strong. Australia, Japan, solid in EU. So from a revenue standpoint, Protiviti's third quarter was pretty much spot on what we expected. They had some gross margin compression, and that compression was less than we expected, actually quite a bit less than we expected. They did a very good job controlling their costs. They used fewer contractors, which is a variable portion of their cost structure. They had fewer experienced hires come on board. So Protiviti, from a profitability standpoint in the third quarter, while not as much as the year ago, which was a tough comp, it was actually pretty significantly better than the guidance we had given for the third quarter. Fourth quarter were still embedded and are guided just mid-single-digit growth. The comps a year ago were again very tough, 15% growth. Profitability remains double digit, notwithstanding it's even shorter quarter for Protiviti because many of their clients have a soft close between Christmas and New Year's, which shortens the effective length of their quarter even more. So clearly, as we've talked about on prior calls, their FSI clients have gotten more cost conscious. That's resulted in fewer hours for us. The hours that we do have are at somewhat lower rates. But overall, all things considered, we were very pleased with the quarter Protiviti had and the one that we're projecting for the fourth.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Then just a follow-up. One of the uncertainty factors that you've reference and I think a lot of others have referenced is just the upcoming election here. Is there any way to sense how big a factor that is? Or how many -- is that something a
componenttext: Understood. Then just a follow-up. One of the uncertainty factors that you've reference and I think a lot of others have referenced is just the upcoming election here. Is there any way to sense how big a factor that is? Or how many -- is that something a lot of clients are mentioning or you're hearing once in a while? Is there any sense that as we get through that, you might see some loosening in some of the trend?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to parse uncertainty between how much of its macro, how much of its -- I have -- my own client financials aren't where I want them to be and therefore, I'm more cost conscious versus the part that's election. I mean, the election uncertainty cer
componenttext: It's hard to parse uncertainty between how much of its macro, how much of its -- I have -- my own client financials aren't where I want them to be and therefore, I'm more cost conscious versus the part that's election. I mean, the election uncertainty certainly didn't help. How much it impacted negatively, it's hard to know. It's certainly part of the discussions that have taken place with our staff and our clients. But precisely what its impact is, is hard to know. And I guess, only time will tell. We look back to some prior election years, and there was a little bit of impact in the quarter prior to the election. But quite frankly, I don't think there's been any election like this election.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll just add that I spent a lot of time talking to executives of other companies and many of our clients. And the elephant in the room probably is the election. Nobody really knows exactly what the impact is. They just know it's much different. You
componenttext: Yes. I'll just add that I spent a lot of time talking to executives of other companies and many of our clients. And the elephant in the room probably is the election. Nobody really knows exactly what the impact is. They just know it's much different. You couple that with anemic GDP growth this year, which has resulted in a tremendous cost consciousness on the part of many clients. It becomes very easy to drag your feet, drag out the hiring process, be very careful about expanding. I would like to think we're going to see an improvement in the horizon here soon after the election, but only time will tell. We don't know for sure. We just know it's a very unusual circumstance. There's been an awful lot of negativity, none of which is great for the economy. So let's see what happens. We hope it's an improvement that occurs.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's interesting for 6 or 7 years, we've been complaining about 2% GDP growth. Now we're sitting here hoping for a GDP growth that's 2% or better, and such an extent you believe we're going to get a 2017 2% or better GDP growth for the year. That's
componenttext: Well, it's interesting for 6 or 7 years, we've been complaining about 2% GDP growth. Now we're sitting here hoping for a GDP growth that's 2% or better, and such an extent you believe we're going to get a 2017 2% or better GDP growth for the year. That's actually an improvement from where we've been, and we would welcome that. We can do just fine with 2-plus GDP growth. It's that 1 and sub 1 and around 1 that's a little tough.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: To analyze your quarterly revenue guidance, I'd broken it down 2 ways. First, looking at the sequential change in revenue per day. Second, looking at your history where actual revenue fell within the guidance range. From this, I have 2 observations. First
componenttext: To analyze your quarterly revenue guidance, I'd broken it down 2 ways. First, looking at the sequential change in revenue per day. Second, looking at your history where actual revenue fell within the guidance range. From this, I have 2 observations. First, your fourth quarter guidance is 300 basis points weaker than we've seen in this expansion. And second, this was the seventh consecutive quarter where revenue came in at or below the midpoint of your guidance range. I have 2 questions. First of all, why is -- I want to get a better understanding of why fourth quarter guidance is so much weaker than normal, even when you're coming off a third quarter that had some disruption effect that's going away? And the other question is what is preventing you from making your revenue guidance ranges more conservative than they've been for almost 2 years?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, why is our fourth quarter guided so much weaker? We're simply looking at current trends all the way through the last week. And based on their trend -- those trends, based on the discussions we've had with our field management teams, those are the ca
componenttext: Well, why is our fourth quarter guided so much weaker? We're simply looking at current trends all the way through the last week. And based on their trend -- those trends, based on the discussions we've had with our field management teams, those are the calls we've made. I'd say as to missing the midpoint of revenue guidance, we've clearly done much better than you referenced at the bottom line. And I would also say that most of those misses, as you call them, have been 1% or 2% misses. So I think for context, we need to talk about the extent of the misses. But further, I'd say we'd call it like it is. And we're not saying baggers [ph], we're not back slappers, and so we try to call it like it is, and we're close. We're usually within 1% or 2% of the revenues, and we're usually at or above the EPS. But where I grew up, coming 98% or 99% of $1 billion more revenue estimate for the quarter isn't bad.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Particularly when there's not exactly a big backlog to take a look at.
componenttext: Particularly when there's not exactly a big backlog to take a look at.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just trying to get a feel for whether there is something about the business that has become a little bit less predictable than you're used to.
componenttext: Yes. I'm just trying to get a feel for whether there is something about the business that has become a little bit less predictable than you're used to.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's fair. I'd say Management Resources is more project-driven than Accountemps. To some degree, Robert Half Technology is more project-driven than Accountemps. Protiviti is certainly more project-driven than traditionally Accountemps. To
componenttext: Well, I think that's fair. I'd say Management Resources is more project-driven than Accountemps. To some degree, Robert Half Technology is more project-driven than Accountemps. Protiviti is certainly more project-driven than traditionally Accountemps. To the extent we've added these additional non-Accountemps services, to some degree, there's a little more volatility because they're more project-driven. But Accountemps itself, I don't think it's gotten anymore variable or volatile. And the classic splits between how accounting operations performed within Accountemps versus how the more staff accountant or financial positions perform within Accountemps, they're all pretty consistent. And I might add that in the third quarter just ended, we reported 3 decent growth in our finance and accounting divisions. It was the non-finance and accounting divisions that lower those rates somewhat.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you believe that permanent placement is acting the way you would have expected it to in past cycles? Do you think you're capturing the share of placements, just total hiring that you would expect to get?
componenttext: Do you believe that permanent placement is acting the way you would have expected it to in past cycles? Do you think you're capturing the share of placements, just total hiring that you would expect to get?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, given how anemic GDP growth has been, it doesn't surprise us the way perm has performed. Perm is always more economically sensitive than is temp. We're seeing that as we speak. It was more impacted in the third quarter, albeit it was on tougher comp
componenttext: Well, given how anemic GDP growth has been, it doesn't surprise us the way perm has performed. Perm is always more economically sensitive than is temp. We're seeing that as we speak. It was more impacted in the third quarter, albeit it was on tougher comps than temp. But I don't believe that we've lost any meaningful share of placements to whether you want to call it technology platforms, other new competitors. If GDP had grown at the same extent that it had in prior cycles and we didn't perform similarly, I think there'd be a credible case to be made that there's a missing delta that we need to talk about. But the fact that GDP hasn't performed and we're essentially back to prior peaks at -- in perm, I think is totally understandable.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kwan Kim on for Tobey. I got a question on the Technology segment. What is your outlook on bill rate growth? And how would you compare that to company average?
componenttext: This is Kwan Kim on for Tobey. I got a question on the Technology segment. What is your outlook on bill rate growth? And how would you compare that to company average?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So bill rates were up 3.5% year-over-year. That was down a little bit from the 4.8% we saw last quarter. That was pretty much down versus last quarter in all of our verticals. It's consistent with all of the commentary we've given already about overall bu
componenttext: So bill rates were up 3.5% year-over-year. That was down a little bit from the 4.8% we saw last quarter. That was pretty much down versus last quarter in all of our verticals. It's consistent with all of the commentary we've given already about overall business conditions, and I'm struggling for it. Does that get at your question? Or was there some other question?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I asked about your outlook.
componenttext: I asked about your outlook.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My outlook. Well, if conditions continue along the current glide path, you would expect to see slightly less bill rate growth. If instead GDP growth picks back up to where it had been, I would not expect the glide path to be downward, but instead to turn
componenttext: My outlook. Well, if conditions continue along the current glide path, you would expect to see slightly less bill rate growth. If instead GDP growth picks back up to where it had been, I would not expect the glide path to be downward, but instead to turn back upward.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned some slowing in order rates on top of a lengthening sales cycle. Can you elaborate on the trends you saw in order flow during the course of the quarter? And what's currently incorporated into your fourth quarter guidance?
componenttext: You mentioned some slowing in order rates on top of a lengthening sales cycle. Can you elaborate on the trends you saw in order flow during the course of the quarter? And what's currently incorporated into your fourth quarter guidance?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With client consciousness, with client lessons of urgency, the order flow rate does slow somewhat. We saw it happened during the quarter. We saw that continue into the fourth quarter. We've extrapolated that trend and considered it in the guidance we've g
componenttext: With client consciousness, with client lessons of urgency, the order flow rate does slow somewhat. We saw it happened during the quarter. We saw that continue into the fourth quarter. We've extrapolated that trend and considered it in the guidance we've given for the fourth quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And now that your new CRM and project management systems have been implemented, can you help quantify what you expect to see in revenue and cost benefits associated with the investment?
componenttext: Great. And now that your new CRM and project management systems have been implemented, can you help quantify what you expect to see in revenue and cost benefits associated with the investment?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the short term, we expect very little short-term benefit from those investments. They're more long-term infrastructure building, platform foundational type of investments that we expect long term but not short-term benefit from.
componenttext: Well, in the short term, we expect very little short-term benefit from those investments. They're more long-term infrastructure building, platform foundational type of investments that we expect long term but not short-term benefit from.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you help frame up what those long-term benefits might be?
componenttext: And can you help frame up what those long-term benefits might be?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- they're cloud-based. We don't have the hosted infrastructure to have to maintain. They're instantly mobily [ph] accessible, which means our staff can sit down with our clients in their offices and have full access to all our databases. As we
componenttext: Well, the -- they're cloud-based. We don't have the hosted infrastructure to have to maintain. They're instantly mobily [ph] accessible, which means our staff can sit down with our clients in their offices and have full access to all our databases. As we offer more and more of our services digitally to our clients and to our candidates, we are -- this enables that to happen in a way that it couldn't happen with our 15-year-old proprietary legacy systems. So exactly how you put a dollar value on that, I would argue quite frankly to remain competitive. In the staffing business, you not only have to offer the traditional services you've always offered, you also have to have digital offerings that are complementary to the traditional offerings you've always had.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari from Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari from Macquarie Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on permanent staffing. Any comments on the recovery you saw in October? And any color on the temp-to-hire conversions you saw during the quarter?
componenttext: I just had a question on permanent staffing. Any comments on the recovery you saw in October? And any color on the temp-to-hire conversions you saw during the quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, our start in perm was better than Q3 in the trends. But as we've said many times, it's only 3 weeks. If you recall last quarter, we hobbled out of the starting gate. I think we were down 17% or something, and we certainty didn't finish the
componenttext: Well, clearly, our start in perm was better than Q3 in the trends. But as we've said many times, it's only 3 weeks. If you recall last quarter, we hobbled out of the starting gate. I think we were down 17% or something, and we certainty didn't finish the quarter anything like that. So quite frankly, perm is volatile. It's more volatile than temp. The start over a 3-week period of time doesn't mean much. That said, I'd rather start better than the prior quarter than worse, which we did. However, our guidance does assume that there would be slight negative year-over-year growth in perm. Temp to hire traditionally follows perm. So just as perm was a little softer than temp this quarter, so was temp to hire as it -- as compared to temp hours billed. It's all about ultimately full-time hiring, the environment for full-time hiring, one follows the other. Clearly, temp to hire in this cycle has been somewhat anemic as has perm generally, but that was also the case in Q3 just ended.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just to follow up. Last question from me. I know the U.K. is a small part of your business at 3% or so. Anything you saw in that market post the Brexit? Or it's too early to tell for you guys?
componenttext: Great. And just to follow up. Last question from me. I know the U.K. is a small part of your business at 3% or so. Anything you saw in that market post the Brexit? Or it's too early to tell for you guys?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say we had a very good quarter on the temporary side in the U.K. The perm side was not as strong. The uncertainty there seems to impact perm more than temp. While we're talking about international, let's not forget we had a very good quarter internati
componenttext: I'd say we had a very good quarter on the temporary side in the U.K. The perm side was not as strong. The uncertainty there seems to impact perm more than temp. While we're talking about international, let's not forget we had a very good quarter internationally, both Protiviti and staffing. Germany continued to do very well. Belgium did well. Australia did well. In Protiviti, Australia did extremely well. We're seeing improvement in Japan for the first time in years, which we're very encouraged by. Generally speaking, international was a bright spot, not only for staffing but for Protiviti. U.K. temp, very good. U.K. perm, not as much.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Leonard filling in for Manav. The comments you make about the clients and just kind of the cautiousness and slower sales cycles, I guess, what would have to change to the downside that would result in you flexing some of the cost leverage you
componenttext: This is Ryan Leonard filling in for Manav. The comments you make about the clients and just kind of the cautiousness and slower sales cycles, I guess, what would have to change to the downside that would result in you flexing some of the cost leverage you mentioned before?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the trends would have to turn more negative, and we're talking about revenues being down 1% in our guidance. And you don't take drastic headcount actions based on a 1% swing, frankly, in either direction. So for us to get much more aggressive on the
componenttext: Well, the trends would have to turn more negative, and we're talking about revenues being down 1% in our guidance. And you don't take drastic headcount actions based on a 1% swing, frankly, in either direction. So for us to get much more aggressive on the cost side, we would have to see much more negative trends than we're seeing. And here again, if the world believes we're going to get 2% plus GDP in 2017, we would see that as an improvement, not a decline.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then just on some of the more digital offerings you've been talking about with the rollout of the new CRM and investment technology. I mean, do you see more investment in technology going forward needed as more and more in terms of staffi
componenttext: Fair enough. And then just on some of the more digital offerings you've been talking about with the rollout of the new CRM and investment technology. I mean, do you see more investment in technology going forward needed as more and more in terms of staffing services go digital?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say yes, we do see more investments needed. They shouldn't be to the extent that we've had the last 2 years where we've essentially done new front office and project management systems in both staffing and Protiviti virtually all at the same time.
componenttext: I would say yes, we do see more investments needed. They shouldn't be to the extent that we've had the last 2 years where we've essentially done new front office and project management systems in both staffing and Protiviti virtually all at the same time. In addition to that, we do have what we call business transformation, which are our innovation initiatives. That will continue, but it's not the lion share of what our CapEx budgets had been the last couple of years. But yes, we do need to continue to spend on technology. We do need to broaden our digital capabilities. I think we're well down that path. We're using artificial intelligence. We're using machine learning. We have client-facing and candidate-facing functionality we've never had before. I think that will only get better as we go forward in time. It will take some investment, but it won't be as much an outsized investment as we've had the last couple of years.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for just one more question. Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon.
componenttext: We have time for just one more question. Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering IFRS rev rec, is that going to be a benefit do you think on the Protiviti side as we look ahead? And if so, what are you hearing from your folks?
componenttext: I was wondering IFRS rev rec, is that going to be a benefit do you think on the Protiviti side as we look ahead? And if so, what are you hearing from your folks?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we think rev rec ultimately will be a single, not a double or a triple. We right now have a lot of diagnostic projects, which are smaller projects in Protiviti where you figure out what the gap is, no pun intended. Frankly, we're probably more excited
componenttext: So we think rev rec ultimately will be a single, not a double or a triple. We right now have a lot of diagnostic projects, which are smaller projects in Protiviti where you figure out what the gap is, no pun intended. Frankly, we're probably more excited but not -- but maybe a double, maybe between a single and a double on lease accounting. Lease accounting is a year further out. Lease accounting is 2019. Rev rec is 2018. They're both helpful. We don't think either of them are going to be major movers of the needle, but we'll take all we can get.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about anything that people should take into consideration for next year outside of the economy? So for example, new overtime regulation. Anything that people should try to factor in?
componenttext: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about anything that people should take into consideration for next year outside of the economy? So for example, new overtime regulation. Anything that people should try to factor in?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say as to the overtime regs, we're dealing with that by changing the salary levels to the extent needed to, which isn't a huge impact. We're also restructuring some of our comp plans otherwise to more or less pay for that. I'd say in 2017, there's
componenttext: I would say as to the overtime regs, we're dealing with that by changing the salary levels to the extent needed to, which isn't a huge impact. We're also restructuring some of our comp plans otherwise to more or less pay for that. I'd say in 2017, there's a change in the tax accounting as it relates to equity compensation that will put pressure on our tax rate. We'll have to figure out precisely what that will be. We'll talk to you about that next quarter. But I think there's going to be a lot more volatility in our tax rate and companies generally because effectively, the impact of your stock price that today equity vest versus the stock price at the day equity was issued that the tax effect of that deferential, you're going to run through P&L for the first time.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was our last question. We'd like to thank everyone again for joining us on today's call.
componenttext: That was our last question. We'd like to thank everyone again for joining us on today's call.

componenttext: This concludes today's teleconference. If you missed any part of this call, it will be archived in audio format in the Investor Center of Robert Half's website at www.roberthalf.com.
