headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer.Mr. Messmer, you may b
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer.
Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Before we get started, I would like to remind everyone there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements repre
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Before we get started, I would like to remind everyone there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds and include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance and similar expressions. We believe these remarks to be reasonable, however, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. Some of these risks and uncertainties are described in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and today's Form 8-K. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on today's call.
For your convenience, our prepared remarks also are available at our website at www.roberthalf.com. From the About Us tab, go to our Investor Center, where you will find the Quarterly Conference Calls link.
Now let's discuss Robert Half's third quarter 2016 results. Revenues for the quarter were $1.339 billion, up 2% from the third quarter 1 year ago. Income per share was $0.71 compared to $0.73 in last year's third quarter. Cash flow from operations was $153 million, and capital expenditures were $20 million in the third quarter.
We paid our stockholders a quarterly cash dividend of $0.22 per share on September 15, for a total cash outlay of $28 million. We also repurchased 1.2 million Robert Half shares during the quarter at a cost of $46 million. We have 7.5 million shares still available for repurchase under our board authorized stock repurchase plan.
We saw solid demand in the third quarter, particularly for our accounting and finance-related professional staffing and consulting services. Our Accountemps and Robert Half Management Resources staffing divisions and Protiviti reported the highest year-over-year revenue gains. Our international operations also posted strong results. Unlevered return on equity for the company remains strong at 33%.
I'll turn the call over to Keith now for a closer look at our third quarter results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As Max mentioned, global revenues were $1.339 billion in the third quarter. This is up 2% from the third quarter 1 year ago on both a reported and same-day, constant currency basis.Let's break this out between our staffing business and Protiv
componenttext:
Thank you. As Max mentioned, global revenues were $1.339 billion in the third quarter. This is up 2% from the third quarter 1 year ago on both a reported and same-day, constant currency basis.
Let's break this out between our staffing business and Protiviti. Global staffing revenues were up 1% in the third quarter on a same-day, constant currency basis from 1 year ago. U.S. staffing revenues were $890 million, roughly flat with last year; and non-U.S. staffing revenues were $231 million, up 7% when adjusted for billing days and exchange rates. We have 326 staffing locations worldwide, including 84 locations in 17 countries outside the United States.
The third quarter had 64.1 billing days compared to 64.2 days in last year's third quarter. The fourth quarter has 61.4 billing days compared to 62.3 days in the fourth quarter of 2015.  
In the third quarter, currency exchange rates had the effect of decreasing reported year-over-year staffing revenues by $3 million. Exchange rates decreased year-over-year reported staffing growth rates by 0.3%.
Third quarter global revenues for Protiviti were $217 million, including $183 million in the United States and $34 million outside the U.S. Overall revenues for Protiviti were up 8% from 1 year ago on a same-day, constant currency basis. U.S. revenues were up 6%, and non-U.S. revenues were up 17% from last year's third quarter. Exchange rates had the effect of decreasing year-over-year Protiviti revenues by $300,000 in the third quarter and decreasing the year-over-year reported growth rate by 0.2%. Protiviti and its independently owned Member Firms serve clients through a network of 75 locations in 25 countries.
Along with our earnings release today, you'll find a supplemental schedule showing year-over-year revenue growth rates on both a reported and same-day, constant currency basis. This data is further broken out by our U.S. and non-U.S. operations. This is a non-GAAP measure we offer to provide insight into certain revenue trends in our operations.
Gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was 37.4% of applicable revenues in the third quarter. This is a 10 basis point improvement from the same period 1 year ago, as higher pay/bill spreads offset slightly lower temp-to-hire conversion revenues.
Third quarter revenues for our permanent placement operations were 9.4% of consolidated staffing revenues, which is down modestly from last year's 10.0%. This modest mix shift caused overall staffing gross margin to decrease by 20 basis points versus 1 year ago to 43.3%.
Gross margin for Protiviti was $67 million in the third quarter or 30.9% of Protiviti revenues. Last year's third quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $66 million or 32.9% of Protiviti revenues.
Staffing SG&A costs were 32.7% of staffing revenues in the third quarter compared to 32.1% in the third quarter 1 year ago.
SG&A costs for Protiviti in the third quarter were 17.9% of Protiviti revenues versus 17.2% of Protiviti revenues in the same period last year.
Operating income from our staffing divisions was $118 million in the third quarter, producing an operating margin of 10.5%. This compares to an operating margin of 11.5% in last year's third quarter. Our temporary and consulting staffing divisions reported $98 million in operating income, resulting in an operating margin of 9.6%.
Operating income for our permanent placement division was $20 million in the third quarter, producing an operating margin of 19.3%. 
Third quarter operating profit for Protiviti was $28 million, yielding an operating margin of 13.0%.
Accounts receivable were $743 million at the end of the third quarter. Implied days sales outstanding, or DSO, was 50.5 days.
During the quarter, we successfully implemented a new front-office CRM system for all U.S. staffing branches and a new project management system for Protiviti. The conversions went smoothly and the related disruption and out-of-pocket costs were at the low end of our previous range. We estimate that revenues and EPS for the quarter were impacted by $9 million and $0.05 per share, respectively.
Before we move to fourth quarter guidance, I'd like to talk about the monthly trends we saw in the third quarter and thus far, in October.
Globally, year-over-year revenue growth rates for our temporary and consulting staffing divisions decelerated during the third quarter, and we exited the quarter with September revenues roughly flat versus the prior year compared to a 2% increase for the full quarter. Revenue growth for our staffing and consulting services in the first 2 weeks of October was down 1.5% compared to the prior year.
Global permanent placement revenue growth rates also decelerated during the first part of the third quarter, with September down 4% compared to the 5% decline for the full quarter. For the first 3 weeks of October, permanent placement revenues increased 1% compared to the same period last year. All of these trends I describe have been normalized for billing days and currency. As you know, we hesitate to read too much into these numbers as they represent very brief periods of time. With that said, we offer the following fourth quarter guidance: revenues, $1,250,000,000 to $1,310,000,000; income per share, $0.60 to $0.66. We limit our guidance to 1 quarter. All estimates we provide on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release and in our SEC filings.
Now I'll turn it back to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. The U.S. economy added fewer jobs in September than economists had expected, and the unemployment rate ticked up slightly to 5%. Unemployment levels in the professional fields we serve remain much lower than the overall U.S. rate, but we
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. The U.S. economy added fewer jobs in September than economists had expected, and the unemployment rate ticked up slightly to 5%. Unemployment levels in the professional fields we serve remain much lower than the overall U.S. rate, but we do continue to see our clients taking longer to make hiring decisions. We have talked about this longer time frame on prior conference calls. Internationally, we continued to see solid growth in many countries, most notably, Germany.
Businesses' appetite for specialized talent in areas important to their growth and profitability remain intact. The -- for computer systems design and related services, for example, the average unemployment rate in the United States is 2.3%. Overall, the average unemployment rate for college degree workers 25 or older is now 2.5%. Employers continue to encounter a widening skills gap in key areas, and they need help finding professionals who are a fit with their needs and work environment.
We were pleased with the results for Protiviti. Protiviti has been doing solid business in all of its practice areas, and it currently works with 70% of Fortune 100 companies. Their sweet spot, of course, is teaming with clients to protect and enhance enterprise value by identifying, anticipating and solving critical business problems.
At this time, Keith and I would be happy to answer your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from RW Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from RW Baird.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Max and Keith, I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color with regards to the pace of deceleration that you ended up seeing over the course of the quarter. And related to that, if you saw clients taking even more time as the quarter progres
componenttext: Max and Keith, I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color with regards to the pace of deceleration that you ended up seeing over the course of the quarter. And related to that, if you saw clients taking even more time as the quarter progressed, you'd spoken about that during the second quarter, so I just wondered if that's changed or if it's gotten incrementally longer? And then also if you could address specifically how the implementation of the CRM system ended up impacting the quarter, just in terms of from a time frame perspective when everything was completed? And what sort of results you're seeing from that new implementation?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, several questions here. On the pace of deceleration, I'd say that July, we actually ended July stronger than we began it. We were encouraged by that. August wasn't bad. But then September, where we usually start getting a sequential lift in Septembe
componenttext: Okay, several questions here. On the pace of deceleration, I'd say that July, we actually ended July stronger than we began it. We were encouraged by that. August wasn't bad. But then September, where we usually start getting a sequential lift in September, we didn't see the lift we typically get. Instead, it was sequentially about flat. And then again, traditionally, we get even more lift yet again in October, and we didn't see that lift either. So it's essentially sequential flattening starting in July rather than the lift we typically see in September and early October. The issue around clients taking more time, I mean, clearly, they remain cautious with little sense of urgency. It's in part due to macro uncertainty, a part due to election uncertainty. They cite budget pressures. They cite cost control measures. They, therefore, get even more selective. They only want your ideal candidates. That in turn pressures candidate supply when they're only looking for the top tranche of the candidate pool you have. They spend more time vetting, they want us to do more interviews. It's not that we have an absence of orders. It's more that the orders that we do have, it just takes longer to get a start if we're on the temp side or it's longer to make a placement if we're on the perm side. So frankly, Mark, it's a continuation of what we've talked about for 2 or 3 quarters, notwithstanding the easier comps. On the Protiviti side, they had very tough comps. Notwithstanding those comps, they still grew mid-single digits. Generally speaking, we were pleased relative to expectations on Protiviti. As to CRM, we were very pleased with the conversion. That happened the week of August 22. Most of the impact, frankly, was during the weeks preceding that where all the training took place, where we essentially took our best producers out of production as they trained the trainers, who in turn trained our staff. So from a financial impact where we first estimated 0.5 day to 1.5 days on the staffing side, it came in closer to 0.5 day. Protiviti came in virtually precisely where we estimated it to be. So from a revenue standpoint, the $9 million splits out to $7 million staffing, $2 million Protiviti. The gross margin of $5 million impact breaks out between $3 million, staffing; $2 million, Protiviti. The SG&A impact was about what we expected at $4.5 million, and that splits out $3.5 million staffing; $1 million, Protiviti. So virtually no surprises on the out-of-pocket cost impact. The revenue disruption impact actually better than we expected. It was quite a large undertaking. We're elated to have it behind us, and we're elated with the capabilities it has and provides to us as we move forward.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On that point, Keith, can you talk a little bit about how quickly you ended up seeing a productivity ramp in your international offices post-implementation?
componenttext: On that point, Keith, can you talk a little bit about how quickly you ended up seeing a productivity ramp in your international offices post-implementation?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so as you're alluding, we did this in 5 countries pre-United States. And the United States experience turned out being very close to what had happened in those 5 countries, even though we worried that the impact would be more. I'd say short term, Ma
componenttext: Well, so as you're alluding, we did this in 5 countries pre-United States. And the United States experience turned out being very close to what had happened in those 5 countries, even though we worried that the impact would be more. I'd say short term, Mark, this isn't about getting more short-term productivity. Short term, it's more about replacing our old 15-year legacy system with something we could maintain, with something that provided global mobile access because it's cloud-based; with something as we move forward in time, as we provide more and more digital services to complement our traditional services, we needed an infrastructure that would facilitate that. So this isn't a short-term productivity play. It's more a long-term, make it easier to support, make it less expensive to support, but more importantly, we needed a platform that we could integrate to the client and candidate-facing services that we intend to provide.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman from JPMorgan.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, I'm going to kind of ask you the question that's the tough one about the cycle. My 20 years of covering staff execs, I don't remember Robert Half trending down outside of a recession, yet our economists are saying real GDP, it looks really solid in
componenttext: Keith, I'm going to kind of ask you the question that's the tough one about the cycle. My 20 years of covering staff execs, I don't remember Robert Half trending down outside of a recession, yet our economists are saying real GDP, it looks really solid in the third and fourth quarter. And I'm just asking you how you could kind of give a little context for the cycle you think we're in right now?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, to reinforce what you've said, I think most economists think we're looking at 2% GDP next year, which frankly would be an uptick from the last -- from the fourth quarter of '15 first 2 of '16 that were sub-2%. Most economists only thin
componenttext: Well, first of all, to reinforce what you've said, I think most economists think we're looking at 2% GDP next year, which frankly would be an uptick from the last -- from the fourth quarter of '15 first 2 of '16 that were sub-2%. Most economists only think there's a 20% chance of a recession in 2017. But one thing we did look at, we have not only bill rates, which by the way, were up 3.5% this quarter year-over-year, which is down a bit from, I believe, it was 4.8% last quarter. So we not only looked at bill rate trends, but we also looked at hours billed trends. And while they've gone slightly negative and are projected to go slightly negative in the fourth quarter, if you look back at 2001 and if you look it back at 2008, they fell much more abruptly than what's implied in what we forecast. So if you just look back at Robert Half volume data, unit data, what we saw in the third quarter, what we're forecasting to the fourth quarter would not be near as abrupt as what we've seen in the past in the early parts of a down cycle.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But there's really no context that you could point to that this is similar to in the past, right?
componenttext: Right. But there's really no context that you could point to that this is similar to in the past, right?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this has been a more sluggish recovery than what we've seen in the past. Some, therefore, surmise that if there's going to be a downturn, it will be less severe as well. But to the extent I compare this to 2001 and 2008, in the early periods of thos
componenttext: Well, this has been a more sluggish recovery than what we've seen in the past. Some, therefore, surmise that if there's going to be a downturn, it will be less severe as well. But to the extent I compare this to 2001 and 2008, in the early periods of those downturns, it drops and drops fairly abruptly. And again, I'm talking hours billed. I'm trying to take rates out of the equation. We have not, nor are we projecting that kind of abrupt negative turn in our volumes.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Keith, if you'll let me, one more question on the Robert Half Technology side. Is that also about just getting a better sense of urgencies in orders? Or is there anything on the recruiting side that you feel like Robert Half Technology has been
componenttext: All right. Keith, if you'll let me, one more question on the Robert Half Technology side. Is that also about just getting a better sense of urgencies in orders? Or is there anything on the recruiting side that you feel like Robert Half Technology has been or could be doing to firm up the revenues on Robert Half Technology?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, on Robert Half Technology, let's not forget the year-ago comps. We grew 15%. So we do have tough comps we're comparing to in Tech. That said, the general trends that I describe also apply to Tech. And as respect to Tech development, wh
componenttext: Well, first of all, on Robert Half Technology, let's not forget the year-ago comps. We grew 15%. So we do have tough comps we're comparing to in Tech. That said, the general trends that I describe also apply to Tech. And as respect to Tech development, which is where we had seen most of our growth, that's now where our growth is most under pressure. And as clients get even more selective even in that area, it further puts pressure on candidate supply. If they'll only take your best candidates, the supply of your best candidates, per se, is a smaller universe than your overall supply, even of solid candidates.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim McHugh from William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim McHugh from William Blair.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, how are you approaching spending at this point? It looked like if I strip through kind of the systems upgrade that you pulled back a little on spending. But I guess, given the trends you are seeing, what's your approach to kind of the staffing leve
componenttext: Keith, how are you approaching spending at this point? It looked like if I strip through kind of the systems upgrade that you pulled back a little on spending. But I guess, given the trends you are seeing, what's your approach to kind of the staffing levels? And as we go into -- even beyond Q4 as we move into '17, how are you managing the structure right now?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the biggest lever we have, as you know, Tim, is our internal recruiter and sales professional headcounts. And the current thinking is to keep them flattish until we get a better sense of exactly where we are. The last thing we want to do is make it sel
componenttext: So the biggest lever we have, as you know, Tim, is our internal recruiter and sales professional headcounts. And the current thinking is to keep them flattish until we get a better sense of exactly where we are. The last thing we want to do is make it self-fulfilling by reducing headcounts in advance of further revenue deceleration. So I would say flattish on heads, they're down slightly in the third quarter. The fourth quarter, our plan is for them to be flat to maybe down slightly again. But we're not intending to do anything precipitous as it relates to our headcounts because we don't see any precipitous decline in our revenues. And like I said, the last thing you want to do is reduce your capacity to sell ahead of actual client demand.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on by -- kind of by the vertical area. The accounting ones have been holding up better, I guess, than clerical and IT. But it seems like you're saying, as the quarter progressed, it was kind of broad based. What -- is there anything you saw
componenttext: Okay. And just on by -- kind of by the vertical area. The accounting ones have been holding up better, I guess, than clerical and IT. But it seems like you're saying, as the quarter progressed, it was kind of broad based. What -- is there anything you saw differently in Accountemps and Management Resources?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say Accountemps, we saw more softness in the accounting operations positions, and those are the ones that are typically more client-demand sensitive, more client-volume sensitive. So it's consistent that if you were to see softness in accounting
componenttext: Well, I'd say Accountemps, we saw more softness in the accounting operations positions, and those are the ones that are typically more client-demand sensitive, more client-volume sensitive. So it's consistent that if you were to see softness in accounting due to macro conditions, you'd see it in accounting operations. In Management Resources, it's all about project ends and starts, and clients were slower to get new projects started than we had expected, which our go-forward guidance anticipates yet again. Management Resources is going to have more variability than Accountemps because it is more project oriented, and that was the case in the third quarter and that's the case in our embedded guidance for the fourth quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Silber from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Silber from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, your last answer is actually a segue to my question. If you can give us a little bit more color by vertical in terms of what's embedded into your guidance for the current quarter, that would be helpful.
componenttext: Keith, your last answer is actually a segue to my question. If you can give us a little bit more color by vertical in terms of what's embedded into your guidance for the current quarter, that would be helpful.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, okay. So by vertical, I'd say, generally speaking, the trend lines you saw during the third quarter would remain intact during the fourth, such that from a staffing perspective, we would see a decline of about 1% year-over-year, same-day, constant c
componenttext: Well, okay. So by vertical, I'd say, generally speaking, the trend lines you saw during the third quarter would remain intact during the fourth, such that from a staffing perspective, we would see a decline of about 1% year-over-year, same-day, constant currency. However, there is 1 fewer day this year than last. There will be a little bit of currency drag so that on a reported basis, your staffing growth rates would be about -- would be down about 3%. And again, the embedded 1% same-day, constant currency is at about the rate we started the quarter. Protiviti grows on a mid-single-digit rate versus their 15% tough year-ago comps. Gross margin, encouragingly, we believe temp gross margins will be up 30 to 50 basis points in the fourth quarter. We've had much better-than-expected experience with our state unemployment costs. We've been conservative for the first part of the year, which will give us some benefit in the fourth quarter. That 30 to 50 basis point improvement does not include potential even further improvement when we get our semiannual workers' comp review, so maybe there's some upside there. Protiviti, similar to the third quarter on a year-on-year basis, their gross margin would be down a couple of points because they've got less mix of the higher-margin FSI, which we've talked about in the past. But again, that's consistent with what we just saw on the SG&A side, on staffing, the dollars year-on-year would be about flat, but as I talked about on a reported basis, you've got revenues down 3% so that's going to create some negative leverage of around 1 point or 100 basis points. Protiviti SG&A would also be up about 100 basis points. Their marketing costs are intended to be higher. They've got higher administrative costs to support their higher headcount. So if you look at our projected operating margins, on the temp side would be down 50 to 70 basis points as the higher gross margin gets offset with the negative leverage in SG&A. Perm would be down about 1 percentage point, same reason. Protiviti would be down 3 to 4 percentage points, still double digit versus a very high 14% a year ago. The tax rate is going to be higher this year than last. We're thinking in the 37.5% range for the fourth quarter. Last year, it was low at 35.3% because we got some discrete credits that won't repeat. Shares before consideration of further buybacks would be in the 127.5 million [ph] range.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really appreciate the thorough answer to that question. And if actually I could just follow up with a couple of numbers related questions. First of all, in the current quarter guidance, is there any more impact of the systems conversion? And if it's pos
componenttext: I really appreciate the thorough answer to that question. And if actually I could just follow up with a couple of numbers related questions. First of all, in the current quarter guidance, is there any more impact of the systems conversion? And if it's possible to give us the average billing days by quarter in 2017, that would be great.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Days by quarter, I have that, but I didn't bring it. Maybe we'll try to get it, and I'll come back before the end of the call with those numbers. As to the system conversion, we do not expect any significant impact during this quarter. Our activity levels
componenttext: Days by quarter, I have that, but I didn't bring it. Maybe we'll try to get it, and I'll come back before the end of the call with those numbers. As to the system conversion, we do not expect any significant impact during this quarter. Our activity levels are pretty much back at the levels they had been pre-conversion. And like I say, hopefully, I could come back to -- well, maybe it's magically appeared sooner. Let's see, 2017 quarter 1, 63.4; quarter 2, 63.3; quarter 3, 63.1; quarter 4, 61.3, to give you a total of 251.1, which is 1 day shorter than 2016.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back on some of the earlier questions and comments. I guess, first off, on the environment and your commentary there. I just wanted to make sure I understood you correctly. Is the sales cycle length about similar from Q2 to Q3? Or do you se
componenttext: I wanted to go back on some of the earlier questions and comments. I guess, first off, on the environment and your commentary there. I just wanted to make sure I understood you correctly. Is the sales cycle length about similar from Q2 to Q3? Or do you see it continuing to sort of lengthen moderately as you're getting into the latter parts of the year?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we talked about, we are seeing it lengthen moderately, and we're also seeing some slowing in order rates because of the uncertainty that I talked about. But we are seeing some lengthening, primarily because they're more selective with the candidates
componenttext: So as we talked about, we are seeing it lengthen moderately, and we're also seeing some slowing in order rates because of the uncertainty that I talked about. But we are seeing some lengthening, primarily because they're more selective with the candidates they'll accept. Those candidates are, in turn, the hardest ones to close because they're the ones with the most options.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then touching on headcount additions again. I think last quarter, you guys had called out growing headcount a little bit. This quarter, you're talking about flattish. And I don't mean to split hairs, but wondering if that's generally con
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then touching on headcount additions again. I think last quarter, you guys had called out growing headcount a little bit. This quarter, you're talking about flattish. And I don't mean to split hairs, but wondering if that's generally consistent quarter-to-quarter? Or should we be reading into that as you're moderating your plans a little bit? And then the second part to that question. You'd spoken to letting attrition play out in areas that aren't really seeing much growth. So would it be fair to say that you're seeing some attrition in segments like OfficeTeam? Perhaps you can just give a sense of where you may be seeing some attrition?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the nature of our business for 30 years is particularly in the first 12 months, there's always attrition. We're a tough team to make. Many times, people that come out of the profession going into a sales and recruiting role is more different than th
componenttext: Well, the nature of our business for 30 years is particularly in the first 12 months, there's always attrition. We're a tough team to make. Many times, people that come out of the profession going into a sales and recruiting role is more different than their functional role in their prior careers. So we've always had a fair amount of attrition during the first 12 months, but it's somewhat variable. So I would say our headcounts didn't turn out that differently than we expected, nor do I expect our Q4 heads are going to be that different than Q3 heads. There's always going to be differences in attrition. You can't peg it exactly, but I wouldn't read anything into. Our overall thought is to keep our headcounts constant and level while we get a better read on demand because the last thing we want to do is essentially have a self-fulfilling prophecy by reducing our capacity.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, your comments on kind of the sequential trends and margins were helpful, but can you just help us frame how much the higher than expected tax rate sapped Q4 EPS? Because it's just the EPS doesn't really reconcile to the revenue even appreciating th
componenttext: Keith, your comments on kind of the sequential trends and margins were helpful, but can you just help us frame how much the higher than expected tax rate sapped Q4 EPS? Because it's just the EPS doesn't really reconcile to the revenue even appreciating that there may be some fixed costs around FX that kind of sapped it a little bit more. But if I have it modeled right, is it $0.03 to $0.04? Is that the way to think about what the higher tax rate in terms of Q4 effect [ph]?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's 2 full points on pretax. Hold on, I mean, I didn't figure it out all the way down to EPS. I mean, we could do the math. Pretax, 120, so 3 million, so that's a couple of pennies back of the envelope. But as I walk down the P&L, I'm basically wal
componenttext: Well, it's 2 full points on pretax. Hold on, I mean, I didn't figure it out all the way down to EPS. I mean, we could do the math. Pretax, 120, so 3 million, so that's a couple of pennies back of the envelope. But as I walk down the P&L, I'm basically walking down the midpoint of our guidance. You've got higher gross margin for reasons I've talked about. The SG&A year-on-year is up about a percentage point as I talked about. The number of shares is down as I talked about. The tax rate is up. So I can assure you, the math works at the midpoint of the range.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one other. We saw a pretty sizable uptick in temp in September. Would that kind of -- the data you have internally, would that lag it? Because we're kind of -- haven't seen that rate of growth since December last year. Is that -- how
componenttext: Got it. And then just one other. We saw a pretty sizable uptick in temp in September. Would that kind of -- the data you have internally, would that lag it? Because we're kind of -- haven't seen that rate of growth since December last year. Is that -- how do you reconcile that, I picked [ph] onto what you're seeing internally, if you would?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you're talking about external...
componenttext: And you're talking about external...

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: BLS [indiscernible]...
componenttext: BLS [indiscernible]...

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: BSA, BLS? I guess, I would observe that over long, long periods of time. We haven't tracked all that closely to either BLS or ASA. It was kind of interesting this morning, PMI Services came out. And if you look at the employment piece of PMI Services, and
componenttext: BSA, BLS? I guess, I would observe that over long, long periods of time. We haven't tracked all that closely to either BLS or ASA. It was kind of interesting this morning, PMI Services came out. And if you look at the employment piece of PMI Services, and I don't call it out because it's the thing, but it just happened to come out this morning. But if you look at the employment portion of PMI Services, it continues to trend down as late as till today. So I -- we've never tracked that closely to the external index as you talked about. Traditionally, they've been very commercial staffing, light industrial production staffing centric. So sometimes, we're better. Sometimes, we're worse, but rarely do we take that much stock in those external indexes.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I wonder if I can get a little more color on Protiviti. It sounds -- you referenced earlier the weaker demand from financial compliance, et cetera. I guess, it sounds like that continues. How it -- any end of the -- light at the end of the tunnel
componenttext: Just -- I wonder if I can get a little more color on Protiviti. It sounds -- you referenced earlier the weaker demand from financial compliance, et cetera. I guess, it sounds like that continues. How it -- any end of the -- light at the end of the tunnel there? And is the pricing pressure you've referenced in the past still a factor with that end market?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Protiviti grew 8% on very tough comps. They grew 23% a year ago, very tough comps. The U.S. was solid. Non-U.S. was very strong. Australia, Japan, solid in EU. So from a revenue standpoint, Protiviti's third quarter was pretty much spot on what we e
componenttext: Well, Protiviti grew 8% on very tough comps. They grew 23% a year ago, very tough comps. The U.S. was solid. Non-U.S. was very strong. Australia, Japan, solid in EU. So from a revenue standpoint, Protiviti's third quarter was pretty much spot on what we expected. They had some gross margin compression, and that compression was less than we expected, actually quite a bit less than we expected. They did a very good job controlling their costs. They used fewer contractors, which is a variable portion of their cost structure. They had fewer experienced hires come on board. So Protiviti, from a profitability standpoint in the third quarter, while not as much as the year ago, which was a tough comp, it was actually pretty significantly better than the guidance we had given for the third quarter. Fourth quarter, we're still -- embedded in our guidance is mid-single-digit growth. The comps a year ago were again very tough, 15% growth. Profitability remains double digit, notwithstanding it's an even shorter quarter for Protiviti because many of their clients have a soft close between Christmas and New Year's, which shortens the effective length of their quarter even more. So clearly, as we've talked about on prior calls, their FSI clients have gotten more cost conscious. That's resulted in fewer hours for us. The hours that we do have are at somewhat lower rates. But overall, all things considered, we were very pleased with the quarter Protiviti had and the one that we're projecting for the fourth.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Then just a follow-up. One of the uncertainty factors that you've referenced and I think a lot of others have referenced is just the upcoming election here. Is there any way to sense how big a factor that is? Or how many -- is that something a
componenttext: Understood. Then just a follow-up. One of the uncertainty factors that you've referenced and I think a lot of others have referenced is just the upcoming election here. Is there any way to sense how big a factor that is? Or how many -- is that something a lot of clients are mentioning or you're hearing once in a while? Is there any sense that, as we get through that, you might see some loosening in some of the trend?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to parse uncertainty between how much of it's macro, how much of it's -- I -- my own client financials aren't where I wanted them to be and, therefore, I'm more cost conscious versus the part that's election. I mean, the election uncertainty cer
componenttext: It's hard to parse uncertainty between how much of it's macro, how much of it's -- I -- my own client financials aren't where I wanted them to be and, therefore, I'm more cost conscious versus the part that's election. I mean, the election uncertainty certainly didn't help. How much it impacted negatively, it's hard to know. It's certainly part of the discussions that have taken place with our staff and our clients. But precisely what its impact is, is hard to know. And I guess, only time will tell. We looked back to some prior election years and there was a little bit of impact in the quarter prior to the election. But quite frankly, I don't think there's been any election like this election.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd just add that I spend a lot of time talking to executives of other companies and many of our clients. And the elephant in the room probably is the election. Nobody really knows exactly what the impact is. They just know it's much different. You c
componenttext: Yes. I'd just add that I spend a lot of time talking to executives of other companies and many of our clients. And the elephant in the room probably is the election. Nobody really knows exactly what the impact is. They just know it's much different. You couple that with anemic GDP growth this year, which has resulted in a tremendous cost consciousness on the part of many clients. It becomes very easy to drag your feet, drag out the hiring process, be very careful about expanding. I would like to think we're going to see an improvement in the horizon here soon after the election, but only time will tell. We don't know for sure. We just know it's a very unusual circumstance. There's been an awful lot of negativity, none of which is great for the economy. So let's see what happens. We hope it's an improvement that occurs.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's interesting for 6 or 7 years, we've been complaining about 2% GDP growth. Now we're sitting here hoping for a GDP growth that's 2% or better, and so to the extent you believe we're going to get a 2017 2% or better GDP growth for the year. That'
componenttext: Well, it's interesting for 6 or 7 years, we've been complaining about 2% GDP growth. Now we're sitting here hoping for a GDP growth that's 2% or better, and so to the extent you believe we're going to get a 2017 2% or better GDP growth for the year. That's actually an improvement from where we've been, and we would welcome that. We can do just fine with 2%-plus GDP growth. It's that 1% and sub 1% and around 1% that's a little tough.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: To analyze your quarterly revenue guidance, I've broken it down 2 ways. First, looking at the sequential change in revenue per day. Second, looking at your history where actual revenue fell within the guidance range. From this, I have 2 observations. Firs
componenttext: To analyze your quarterly revenue guidance, I've broken it down 2 ways. First, looking at the sequential change in revenue per day. Second, looking at your history where actual revenue fell within the guidance range. From this, I have 2 observations. First, your fourth quarter guidance is 300 basis points weaker than we've seen in this expansion. And second, this was the seventh consecutive quarter where revenue came in at or below the midpoint of your guidance range. And I have 2 questions. First of all, why is -- I want to get a better understanding of why fourth quarter guidance is so much weaker than normal, even when you're coming off a third quarter that had some disruption effect that's going away? And the other question is what is preventing you from making your revenue guidance ranges more conservative than they've been for almost 2 years?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, why is our fourth quarter guided so much weaker? We're simply looking at current trends all the way through last week. And based on their trend -- those trends, based on the discussions we've had with our field management teams, those are the calls
componenttext: Well, why is our fourth quarter guided so much weaker? We're simply looking at current trends all the way through last week. And based on their trend -- those trends, based on the discussions we've had with our field management teams, those are the calls we've made. I'd say as to missing the midpoint of revenue guidance, we've clearly done much better than you referenced at the bottom line. And I would also say that most of those misses, as you call them, have been 1% or 2% misses. So I think for context, we need to talk about the extent of the misses. But further, I'd say we call it like it is. And we're not sand baggers, we're not back slappers, and so we try to call it like it is, and we're close. We're usually within 1% or 2% of the revenues, and we're usually at or above the EPS. But where I grew up, coming 98% or 99% of $1 billion more revenue estimate for the quarter isn't bad.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Particularly when there's not exactly a big backlog to take a look at.
componenttext: Particularly when there's not exactly a big backlog to take a look at.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just trying to get a feel for whether there is something about the business that has become a little bit less predictable than you're used to.
componenttext: Yes. I'm just trying to get a feel for whether there is something about the business that has become a little bit less predictable than you're used to.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's fair. I'd say Management Resources is more project-driven than Accountemps. To some degree, Robert Half Technology is more project-driven than Accountemps. Protiviti is certainly more project-driven than, traditionally, Accountemps. T
componenttext: Well, I think that's fair. I'd say Management Resources is more project-driven than Accountemps. To some degree, Robert Half Technology is more project-driven than Accountemps. Protiviti is certainly more project-driven than, traditionally, Accountemps. To the extent we've added these additional non-Accountemps services, to some degree, there's a little more volatility because they're more project-driven. But Accountemps itself, I don't think it's gotten anymore variable or volatile. And the classic split between how accounting operations performs within Accountemps versus how the more staff accountant or financial positions perform within Accountemps, they're all pretty consistent. And I might add that in the third quarter just ended, we reported pretty decent growth in our finance and accounting divisions. It was the non-finance and accounting divisions that lowered those rates somewhat.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you believe that permanent placement is acting the way you would have expected it to in past cycles? Do you think you're capturing the share of placements, just total hiring, that you would expect to get?
componenttext: Do you believe that permanent placement is acting the way you would have expected it to in past cycles? Do you think you're capturing the share of placements, just total hiring, that you would expect to get?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, given how anemic GDP growth has been, it doesn't surprise us the way perm has performed. Perm is always more economically sensitive than is temp. We're seeing that as we speak. It was more impacted in the third quarter, albeit it was on tougher comp
componenttext: Well, given how anemic GDP growth has been, it doesn't surprise us the way perm has performed. Perm is always more economically sensitive than is temp. We're seeing that as we speak. It was more impacted in the third quarter, albeit it was on tougher comps than temp. But I don't believe that we've lost any meaningful share of placements to whether you want to call it technology platforms, other new competitors. If GDP had grown at the same extent that it had in prior cycles and we didn't perform similarly, I think there'd be a credible case to be made that there's a missing delta that we need to talk about. But the fact that GDP hasn't performed and we're essentially back to prior peaks at -- in perm, I think is totally understandable.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kwan Kim on for Tobey. I've got a question on the Technology segment. What is your outlook on bill rate growth? And how would you compare that to the company average?
componenttext: This is Kwan Kim on for Tobey. I've got a question on the Technology segment. What is your outlook on bill rate growth? And how would you compare that to the company average?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So bill rates were up 3.5% year-over-year. That was down a little bit from the 4.8% we saw last quarter. That was pretty much down versus last quarter in all of our verticals. It's consistent with all of the commentary we've given already about overall bu
componenttext: So bill rates were up 3.5% year-over-year. That was down a little bit from the 4.8% we saw last quarter. That was pretty much down versus last quarter in all of our verticals. It's consistent with all of the commentary we've given already about overall business conditions, and I'm struggling for it. Does that get at your question? Or was there some other question?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I asked about your outlook.
componenttext: I asked about your outlook.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My outlook. Well, if conditions continue along the current glide path, you would expect to see slightly less bill rate growth. If instead GDP growth picks back up to where it had been, I would not expect the glide path to be downward, but instead to turn
componenttext: My outlook. Well, if conditions continue along the current glide path, you would expect to see slightly less bill rate growth. If instead GDP growth picks back up to where it had been, I would not expect the glide path to be downward, but instead to turn back upward.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've mentioned some slowing in order rates on top of a lengthening sales cycle. Can you elaborate on the trends you saw in order flow during the course of the quarter? And what's currently incorporated into your fourth quarter guidance?
componenttext: You've mentioned some slowing in order rates on top of a lengthening sales cycle. Can you elaborate on the trends you saw in order flow during the course of the quarter? And what's currently incorporated into your fourth quarter guidance?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With client cautiousness, with client lessens [ph] of urgency, the order flow rate does slow somewhat. We saw it happen during the quarter. We saw that continue into the fourth quarter. We've extrapolated that trend and considered it in the guidance we've
componenttext: With client cautiousness, with client lessens [ph] of urgency, the order flow rate does slow somewhat. We saw it happen during the quarter. We saw that continue into the fourth quarter. We've extrapolated that trend and considered it in the guidance we've given for the fourth quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And now that your new CRM and project management systems have been implemented, can you help quantify what you expect to see in revenue and cost benefits associated with the investment?
componenttext: Great. And now that your new CRM and project management systems have been implemented, can you help quantify what you expect to see in revenue and cost benefits associated with the investment?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the short term, we expect very little short-term benefit from those investments. They're more long-term infrastructure building, platform foundational type of investments that we expect long term but not short-term benefit from.
componenttext: Well, in the short term, we expect very little short-term benefit from those investments. They're more long-term infrastructure building, platform foundational type of investments that we expect long term but not short-term benefit from.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you help frame up what those long-term benefits might be?
componenttext: And can you help frame up what those long-term benefits might be?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- they're cloud-based. We don't have the hosted infrastructure to have to maintain. They're instantly mobily accessible, which means our staff can sit down with our clients in their offices and have full access to all our databases. As we offer
componenttext: Well, the -- they're cloud-based. We don't have the hosted infrastructure to have to maintain. They're instantly mobily accessible, which means our staff can sit down with our clients in their offices and have full access to all our databases. As we offer more and more of our services digitally to our clients and to our candidates, we are -- this enables that to happen in a way that it couldn't happen with our 15-year-old proprietary legacy systems. So exactly how you put a dollar value on that, I would argue, quite frankly, to remain competitive in the staffing business, you not only have to offer the traditional services you've always offered, you also have to have digital offerings that are complementary to the traditional offerings you've always had.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari from Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari from Macquarie Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on permanent staffing. Any comments on the recovery you saw in October? And any color on the temp-to-hire conversions you saw during the quarter?
componenttext: I just had a question on permanent staffing. Any comments on the recovery you saw in October? And any color on the temp-to-hire conversions you saw during the quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, our start in perm was better than Q3 and the trends. But as we've said many times, it's only 3 weeks. If you recall last quarter, we hobbled out of the starting gate. I think we were down 17% or something, and we certainly didn't finish the
componenttext: Well, clearly, our start in perm was better than Q3 and the trends. But as we've said many times, it's only 3 weeks. If you recall last quarter, we hobbled out of the starting gate. I think we were down 17% or something, and we certainly didn't finish the quarter anything like that. So quite frankly, perm is volatile. It's more volatile than temp. The start over a 3-week period of time doesn't mean much. That said, I'd rather start better than the prior quarter than worse, which we did. However, our guidance does assume that there would be slight negative year-over-year growth in perm. Temp-to-hire traditionally follows perm. So just as perm was a little softer than temp this quarter, so was temp-to-hire as it -- as compared to temp hours billed. It's all about, ultimately full-time hiring, the environment for full-time hiring, one follows the other. Clearly, temp-to-hire in this cycle has been somewhat anemic as has perm generally, but that was also the case in Q3 just ended.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a follow-up last question from me. I know the U.K. is a small part of your business at 3% or so. Anything you saw in that market post the Brexit? Or it's too early to tell for you guys?
componenttext: Great. And just a follow-up last question from me. I know the U.K. is a small part of your business at 3% or so. Anything you saw in that market post the Brexit? Or it's too early to tell for you guys?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say we had a very good quarter on the temporary side in the U.K. The perm side was not as strong. The uncertainty there seems to impact perm more than temp. While we're talking about international, let's not forget we had a very good quarter internati
componenttext: I'd say we had a very good quarter on the temporary side in the U.K. The perm side was not as strong. The uncertainty there seems to impact perm more than temp. While we're talking about international, let's not forget we had a very good quarter internationally, both Protiviti and staffing. Germany continued to do very well. Belgium did well. Australia did well. In Protiviti, Australia did extremely well. We're seeing improvement in Japan for the first time in years, which we're very encouraged by. Generally speaking, international was a bright spot, not only for staffing but for Protiviti. U.K. temp, very good. U.K. perm, not as much.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Leonard filling in for Manav. The comments you make about the clients and just kind of the cautiousness and some of those slower sales cycles, I guess, what would have to change to the downside that would result in you flexing some of the cos
componenttext: This is Ryan Leonard filling in for Manav. The comments you make about the clients and just kind of the cautiousness and some of those slower sales cycles, I guess, what would have to change to the downside that would result in you flexing some of the cost leverage you mentioned before?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the trends would have to turn more negative, I mean, we're talking about revenues being down 1% in our guidance. And you don't take drastic headcount actions based on a 1% swing, frankly, in either direction. So for us to get much more aggressive on
componenttext: Well, the trends would have to turn more negative, I mean, we're talking about revenues being down 1% in our guidance. And you don't take drastic headcount actions based on a 1% swing, frankly, in either direction. So for us to get much more aggressive on the cost side, we would have to see much more negative trends than we're seeing. And here again, if the world believes we're going to get 2% plus GDP in 2017, we would see that as an improvement, not a decline.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then just on some of the more digital offerings you've been talking about with the rollout of the new CRM and investment in technology. I mean, do you see more investment in technology going forward needed as more and more kind of staffin
componenttext: Fair enough. And then just on some of the more digital offerings you've been talking about with the rollout of the new CRM and investment in technology. I mean, do you see more investment in technology going forward needed as more and more kind of staffing services go digital?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say yes, we do see more investments needed. They shouldn't be to the extent that we've had the last 2 years where we've essentially done new front office and project management systems in both staffing and Protiviti virtually all at the same time.
componenttext: I would say yes, we do see more investments needed. They shouldn't be to the extent that we've had the last 2 years where we've essentially done new front office and project management systems in both staffing and Protiviti virtually all at the same time. In addition to that, we do have what we call business transformation, which are our innovation initiatives. That will continue, but it's not the lion share of what our CapEx budgets have been the last couple of years. But yes, we do need to continue to spend on technology. We do need to broaden our digital capabilities. I think we're well down that path. We're using artificial intelligence. We're using machine learning. We have client-facing and candidate-facing functionality we've never had before. I think that will only get better as we go forward in time. It will take some investment, but it won't be as much an outsized investment as we've had the last couple of years.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for just one more question. Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon.
componenttext: We have time for just one more question. Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering IFRS rev rec, is that going to be a benefit do you think on the Protiviti side as we look ahead? And if so, what are you hearing from your folks?
componenttext: I was wondering IFRS rev rec, is that going to be a benefit do you think on the Protiviti side as we look ahead? And if so, what are you hearing from your folks?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we think rev rec, ultimately, will be a single, not a double or a triple. We right now have a lot of diagnostic projects, which are smaller projects in Protiviti where you figure out what the gap is, no pun intended. Frankly, we're probably more excite
componenttext: So we think rev rec, ultimately, will be a single, not a double or a triple. We right now have a lot of diagnostic projects, which are smaller projects in Protiviti where you figure out what the gap is, no pun intended. Frankly, we're probably more excited but not -- but maybe a double, maybe between a single and a double on lease accounting. Lease accounting is a year further out. Lease accounting is 2019. Rev rec is 2018. They're both helpful. We don't think either of them are going to be major movers of the needle, but we'll take all we can get.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about anything that people should take into consideration for next year outside of the economy? So for example, new overtime regulations. Anything that people should try to factor in?
componenttext: Great. And then can you talk a little bit about anything that people should take into consideration for next year outside of the economy? So for example, new overtime regulations. Anything that people should try to factor in?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say as to the overtime regs, we're dealing with that by changing the salary levels to the extent needed to, which isn't a huge impact. We're also restructuring some of our comp plans otherwise to more or less pay for that. I'd say in 2017, there's
componenttext: I would say as to the overtime regs, we're dealing with that by changing the salary levels to the extent needed to, which isn't a huge impact. We're also restructuring some of our comp plans otherwise to more or less pay for that. I'd say in 2017, there's a change in the tax accounting as it relates to equity compensation that will put pressure on our tax rate. We'll have to figure out precisely what that will be. We'll talk to you about that next quarter. But I think there's going to be a lot more volatility in our tax rate and companies generally because effectively, the impact of your stock price that today equity vests versus the stock price at the day equity was issued that the tax effect of that deferential, you're going to run through P&L for the first time.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was our last question. We'd like to thank everyone again for joining us on today's call.
componenttext: That was our last question. We'd like to thank everyone again for joining us on today's call.

componenttext: This concludes today's teleconference. If you missed any part of this call, it will be archived in audio format in the Investor Center of Robert Half's website at www.roberthalf.com. You can also dial the conference call replay. Dial-in details and the conference ID are contained in the company's press release issued earlier today.
